Ostanin indicates that this is also a reference to the following proverb: “Петр и Павел час убавил, а Илья Пророк два уволок” (Peter and Paul stole an hour, and Ilya the Prophet took away two) (35). The exact quantities are not actually correct, but the meaning is that on these saints respective days (July 12 and August 2) the sun moves faster than on the longest days of summer.

explanatory time intertextuality
conclusion

It is presumably the end of summer, since Ilya intends to celebrate the “end” of his seasonal work.

time explanatory
business

His seasonal work.

explanatory
I met a certain blind man in an unsightly place, and he volunteered to accompany me to the water for repose. And I trudged after him, trustin him in everythin, but the darkness engulfed us and for that reason he did not notice a huntin pit and tumbled in. I also fell in, followin the leader, ’cuz my belt was tied to his with a strong rope so we wouldn’t get separated

A reference to Matthew 15:14 (“If the blind lead the blind, both will fall into a pit”) and Bruegel the Elder’s 1568 painting The Blind Leading the Blind. This segment is Ilya’s direct speech to the people gathered in the “crashbaret,” to whom he recounts what has happened to him. However, given the fact that Ilya is also by his name and character linked to the prophet Elijah, his story turns into an allegoric parable in order to help Petr understand the origin of the letter zhe (and presumably, to find the drozhzhy, yeast, he is searching for).

intertextuality Bible religion character foreign
blind man

One more character with disability in this novel.

character structure
comrades in misfortune

It may conceal an allusion to the expression “друзья познаются в беде” (friends in need), from the Latin “amicus certus in re incerta.”

phraseologism
The main wheel had cracked in many places

A first explanation of the origin/birth of the letter zhe (that is, the result of the breaking up of Ilya’s grinding stand).

intratextuality explanatory
I was returnin to the winter quarters

Ostanin identifies this as an allusion to Mikhail Lermontov’s 1837 poem “Borodino”: “Что ж мы? на зимние квартиры?” (35). Read the poem and an English translation here. Responding to a question regarding similarities between his style and that of Vladimir Nabokov, Sokolov said, “I’ve surmized that a similarity in our styles might come from a common source: We share favorite writers. It may be enough to point to Gogol’ and Lermontov. By connecting these two, a system of coordinates appears, from which one can determine style. Of course, only if both writers are favorites” (Podshivalov, “A Conversation” 353). For more on Sokolov and Nabokov, see D. Barton Johnson’s “Saša Sokolov and Vladimir Nabokov.” There, the critic writes, “After arriving in Vienna in October 1975, Sokolov read (in Russian) Lolita and The Gift and was surprised to note similarities between the avant-garde prose style of Škola dlja durakov and Nabokov’s prose techniques […] Dismayed, Sokolov determined to develop a new, distinctive voice, one not under the shadow of the older writer. This search led to the exotic language of his 1980 Meždu sobakoj i volkom” (154). Evgeny Sokolov calls Between Dog and Wolf a “poema squared,” riffing on Gogol’s characterization of his novel Dead Souls as a poema (10).

intertextuality
with empty pockets and nothin clinked in them

As elsewhere in the novel, Ilya does not have any money.

intratextuality character
Hay-rot season

Rainy weather or a long rain during hay season that will bring rot. Maybe also refer to long rainy weather in spring, summer, or autumn. Also refers to St. Samson’s day (June 27 OS / July 10 NS). As Boguslawski writes, folk tradition holds that on this date “the rains begin, which often continue for a week, causing the cut but not gathered hay to rot. For this reason, the saint is often called Sampson the Hay-rot” (“Annotations” 238).

explanatory time
Beside myself

Also a reference to Ilya and the other characters’ unusual sense of self, whereby their names and identities frequently shift.

character
the rim finally split in two and fell apart

A second explanation of the origin/birth of the letter zhe (that is, the result of the breaking up of Ilya’s grinding stand in two).

explanatory intratextuality
at my feet

Ilya appears to have both of his feet here, but, of course, he has lost one in an accident involving a train.

character intratextuality
lot

The Lonesome Babe refers to Ilya’s “участь бродячья” (nomadic lot/fate) not long after this (R177/E48-49).

intratextuality
I took it out, threw it on the floor, and spat

Enumeration.

register/style
And the crosspiece fell precisely between them, between them two rim fragments, while they were lyin sorta resemblin two thin crescents, with backs to each other and with faces—here and there: one young, the other Krylobyl, on the wane

Ilya describes how his grinding machine’s parts have split and given shape, as Krylobyl will suggest momentarily, to the missing letter: ж.

explanatory language intratextuality
two thin crescents

Ostanin makes the clever observation that Sokolov’s initials in Cyrillic also make two crescent moons: С. С. (36).

self-reference
Krylobyl

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in this chapter it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Towards the end of the novel, he will be addressed by Ilya as “Fedot Fyodorov.”

character intertextuality
Krylobyl

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in this chapter it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Towards the end of the novel, he will be addressed by Ilya as “Fedot Fyodorov.”

character intertextuality
Pozhilykh

An unusual surname that does not permit standard declination. It literally means Elderly. Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak’s novel Doctor Zhivago by means of the root “zhiv” (to live) (10). Read the original here. Likewise, he notes that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled “Notes of an Elderly Person” in his cycle of short stories, The Tales of Belkin. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Martina Napolitano observes, “Pozhilykh, Ilya’s addressee, is once ‘transfigured’ into an alleged Resurrection painting whose title plays on the ambiguity of his last name – Voskresenie Pozhilykh, The Resurrection of the Elderly. Ilya indeed concludes his letter wishing Pozhilykh “a happy resurrection”: this is his final message, his “good news.” It literally is his Gospel, from the Greek εὐαγγέλιον (good news); in the original, Ilya here distorts the canonical blagaia vest’ in ‘blagoe izvestie’” (“Studyin” 286).

character intertextuality religion
fish fur

Literal: fish fur. Set expression meaning poor-quality winter-weather clothing. Derived from the Russian proverb “A poor man’s fur coat is of fish fur” (У бедняка шуба на рыбьем меху). Such furs were used by the Soviet Army; given the number and kinds of wounds on display by the residents of the novel’s community, it can be assumed that many of them are veterans. Today, the phrase also refers to fake fur. Animal motif.

explanatory intertextuality phraseologism
rotgut

Poor quality, potentially dangerous alcohol. Alcohol theme.

theme
moonfaced

This neologism reflects the original, mesyatseliky. It also creates a semantic connection with the “wane” (moon waning) mentioned before, which is even more present in the original through the repetition of the term “usherbnoy” in different contexts.

neologism translation symbol
Pyotr

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign religion intertextuality
Lukich

Patronymic: “son of Luka.”

character
Ain’t the thing thrown on the floor by one beggar a treasure for another one

A play on the proverb “что для одного мусор, для другого клад” (one man’s trash is another’s treasure).

phraseologism
lyin in the dust of this sickler

This phrase is repeated a few lines below.

intratextuality
sickler

A tavern or bar where customers drink to excess, resulting in sickness. Gerald Smith appropriately calls Between Dog and Wolf “one of the most sustained and elaborated drinking songs in the whole of Russian literature” (“The Verse” 330). Alcohol theme.

theme setting location
Pyotr

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign religion intertextuality
Krylobyl

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in this chapter it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Towards the end of the novel, he will be addressed by Ilya as “Fedot Fyodorov.”

character intertextuality
Krylobyl teaches the one bein taught in the crashbaret on the hill

Later echoed in chapter 6: “Учить себя никому не позволю, Фома заявил” (“I won’t allow anyone to lecture me, noted Foma”) (R194/E80).

intratextuality
teaches the one bein taught

Proverb: Учёного учить — только портить (Don’t offer to teach a fish to swim; teaching your grandmother to suck eggs).

phraseologism
crashbaret

A drinking establishment. Original Russia: кубаре (kubare). A mixture of kubarem (to fall head over heels) and the French “cabaret.” Customers, of course, will fall over and crash to the floor if they drink too much. The name of the establishment is literalized in this way. On Sokolov’s use of neologisms, see Brainina.

setting location neologism language
You are speakin in riddles, Pyotr said to Krylobyl, you’re teachin in riddles, to Krylobyl said Pyotr, oh, in riddles

Approximately what readers do with this novel, guessing riddles.

structure
Pyotr

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign religion intertextuality
Krylobyl

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in this chapter it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Towards the end of the novel, he will be addressed by Ilya as “Fedot Fyodorov.”

character intertextuality
Krylobyl

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in this chapter it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Towards the end of the novel, he will be addressed by Ilya as “Fedot Fyodorov.”

character intertextuality
Pyotr

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign religion intertextuality
Yourses

Mock imitation of high register (instead of “Yours”).

register/style
just licked his lips

He simply licked his lips, because of his lack of money.

explanatory character
Krylobyl

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in this chapter it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Towards the end of the novel, he will be addressed by Ilya as “Fedot Fyodorov.”

character intertextuality
zhe-zhe-zhe

The missing letter/sound is found. Ostanin (36) mentions the existence of a small tributary to the Volga, called Shosha, situated near Gorodishche, whose name echoes the sound of water flowing.

explanatory location
Krylobyl

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in this chapter it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Towards the end of the novel, he will be addressed by Ilya as “Fedot Fyodorov.”

intertextuality character
Pyotr

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign religion intertextuality
lyin in the dust of this sickler

This phrase is used a few lines above.

intratextuality
sickler

A tavern or bar where customers drink to excess, resulting in sickness. Gerald Smith appropriately calls Between Dog and Wolf “one of the most sustained and elaborated drinking songs in the whole of Russian literature” (“The Verse” 330). Alcohol theme.

theme setting location
Pyotr

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign religion intertextuality
treat

Here used with reference to alcohol. Alcohol theme.

theme register/style
Krylobyl

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in this chapter it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Towards the end of the novel, he will be addressed by Ilya as “Fedot Fyodorov.”

character intertextuality
Pyotr

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign religion intertextuality
Manul

A manul, also known as the Pallas’s cat, is a wild cat first documented near Lake Baikal. Ostanin suggests that this character’s name is also a shortened form of Emmanuel, which means “God with us” (16). Ilya references a “manul’s eyes” in chapter 6 (R192/E76). Animal motif.

motif intratextuality character
Manul

A manul, also known as the Pallas’s cat, is a wild cat first documented near Lake Baikal. Ostanin suggests that this character’s name is also a shortened form of Emmanuel, which means “God with us” (16). Ilya references a “manul’s eyes” in chapter 6 (R192/E76). Animal motif.

motif intratextuality character
Manul

A manul, also known as the Pallas’s cat, is a wild cat first documented near Lake Baikal. Ostanin suggests that this character’s name is also a shortened form of Emmanuel, which means “God with us” (16). Ilya references a “manul’s eyes” in chapter 6 (R192/E76). Animal motif.

motif intratextuality character
Manul

A manul, also known as the Pallas’s cat, is a wild cat first documented near Lake Baikal. Ostanin suggests that this character’s name is also a shortened form of Emmanuel, which means “God with us” (16). Ilya references a “manul’s eyes” in chapter 6 (R192/E76). Animal motif.

intratextuality character motif
light bay

Boguslawski comments that “the narrator applies equine terminology to describe the woman working in the bar” (“Annotations” 238). In the original the woman is described as pale yellow, but the term used, solovaya, may also mean dull or sluggish from intoxication. Alcohol theme.

theme translation
Manul

A manul, also known as the Pallas’s cat, is a wild cat first documented near Lake Baikal. Ostanin suggests that this character’s name is also a shortened form of Emmanuel, which means “God with us” (16). Ilya references a “manul’s eyes” in chapter 6 (R192/E76). Animal motif.

motif intratextuality character
Manul set out to have a talk with the inspector in the Other Places, and came back only three years ago

This scene gives more context to one from chapter 1 (R152/E6).

intratextuality
at real cost

He came back after being dumped and continued gambling with renewed vigor, like he has nothing to lose.

explanatory
anaconda purses

Snakeskin purse. The phrase suggests that their money is swallowed up. Animal motif.

motif explanatory
Pyotr

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign religion intertextuality
Manul

A manul, also known as the Pallas’s cat, is a wild cat first documented near Lake Baikal. Ostanin suggests that this character’s name is also a shortened form of Emmanuel, which means “God with us” (16). Ilya references a “manul’s eyes” in chapter 6 (R192/E76). Animal motif.

motif intratextuality character
Pyotr

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign religion intertextuality
Exetera

Instead of “et cetera,” to suggest Ilya’s illiteracy.

register/style translation
Pyotr

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign religion intertextuality
Manul

A manul, also known as the Pallas’s cat, is a wild cat first documented near Lake Baikal. Ostanin suggests that this character’s name is also a shortened form of Emmanuel, which means “God with us” (16). Ilya references a “manul’s eyes” in chapter 6 (R192/E76). Animal motif.

intratextuality character motif
Pyotr

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

foreign religion intertextuality character
Manul

A manul, also known as the Pallas’s cat, is a wild cat first documented near Lake Baikal. Ostanin suggests that this character’s name is also a shortened form of Emmanuel, which means “God with us” (16). Ilya references a “manul’s eyes” in chapter 6 (R192/E76). Animal motif.

motif character intratextuality
upstreamer

Neologism: someone from upstream, from the Upper Volga.

neologism
Manul

A manul, also known as the Pallas’s cat, is a wild cat first documented near Lake Baikal. Ostanin suggests that this character’s name is also a shortened form of Emmanuel, which means “God with us” (16). Ilya references a “manul’s eyes” in chapter 6 (R192/E76). Animal motif.

character motif intratextuality
Sidor Fomich

The investigator for special cases Pozhilykh to whom Ilya is addressing his letter.

character intratextuality
Ain’t no misfortune without good fortune

A variation of the phraseologism “нет худа без добра” (“every cloud has a silver lining”).

phraseologism
Dzynzyrela

Another variation on Ilya’s unusual last name, which is printed in more than ten different versions in the book. It carries allusions to Cinderella (see L. Toker’s essay, “Gamesman’s Sketches (Found in a Bottle),” CASS 21.3-4: 356). However, as Korovashko suggests, “Ilya Petrikevich becomes a kind of Cinderella ‘squared’: if the latter lost only his shoe, he lost both his leg and the crutches that compensate for its absence” (277).

character intertextuality
And the river answers my request: I will give you a stone to put either under your head or on your neck—take it, be my guest, but in the latter case don’t blame me, you won’t eat them mussels to your health, alas, but they will eat you with pleasure

A continuation of the end of chapter 1 and Ilya’s conversation with the river (R158/E16). Here, the “Страшнеющего Суда” becomes “последнем случае.” The threat of death and the pull of suicide looms over Ilya and many of the men living on the banks of the Volga.

intratextuality explanatory theme
mussels

In chapter 1, Ilya describes his love of mussels — a sexual symbol in the novel (R158/E16). Associated with Orina. Saint James the Great’s emblem features a mussel. Animal motif.

intratextuality symbol religion motif bible
mussels

In chapter 1, Ilya describes his love of mussels — a sexual symbol in the novel (R158/E16). Associated with Orina. Saint James the Great’s emblem features a mussel. Animal motif.

intertextuality symbol religion motif bible
at dusk

Again at twilight.

time theme
pantofle

D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif intertextuality
says

This is the river’s reply: it invites Ilya to enter its waters.

explanatory
galife

A type of trousers, typical for the army. Named after Gaston Alexandre Auguste, Marquis de Galliffet, a French general. Clothing motif.

motif foreign
fryin, boilin, bakin

Enumeration.

register/style
unsofiscated

Instead of “unsophisticated,” to suggest Ilya’s illiteracy.

register/style translation
They get bigger every passin year; I am witherin, wiltin

Ilya is growing thinner year after year (so his clothes are becoming bigger).

explanatory character
lonesome babe

She will make several appearances throughout the novel and is associated with Orina.

character
I repent, I repent, I attached myself to her without wakin up the sacred feelins, just to have a harbor, a warm bench, or a couch to throw my bones on

Ilya is regretful about how he treated his partner: instead of nourishing “high sentiments”, he simply saw in her a “pied-à-terre,” a “warm bench or bed.”

explanatory character
to throw my bones on

Boguslawski translates literally this Russian phraseologism meaning to find a shelter.

neologism translation
the bed is dank

The bed is humid, much as the Volga River (echoed in the original through the adjective, volglo) invites Ilya to sleep at its bottom.

sound play explanatory intratextuality
scares-nightmares

In the original (mordasti) there is a direct allusion to the folk song “Pridut Strasti-Mordasti” and Maxim Gorky’s 1913 short story, which references the song. Read the text in Russian here.

intertextuality
lonesome babe

She will make several appearances throughout the novel and is associated with Orina.

character
my flesh is dryin out ’cuz I have no strength to forget Orina

Ilya cannot forget Orina and this makes the woman suffer. Ilya uses the same verb he used to describe himself getting thinner and thinner (“sokhnu”, I dry up), but while in regard to himself this process is linked with his living a hard life, here the woman accuses him to make his flesh “dry up.” The verb is repeated one more time in the next sentence, yet with a prefix (pri-), as she observes that Ilya “dried up” sticking himself to Orina, that is to say: he cannot forget Orina.

explanatory character language
you grab me

Ilya while sleeping grabs the woman roughly, as if he hadn’t hands but paws (“lapy”, in Russian, concelaed in the verb oblaplivat’). Once again he is associated with animals. Animal-human motif.

motif character register/style
puppy

Again Ilya is associated with animals. Animal-human motif.

motif character register/style
tart

In the original, the derogatory term used here is “lyarva,” a word which in Ancient Rome, larva, had a different meaning: it indicated the spirit of an evil person who has died and brings harm to the living.

register/style character translation
Sidor Fomich

The investigator for special cases Pozhilykh to whom Ilya is addressing his letter.

character intratextuality
mantilla

A Spanish lace veil or clock for women. Here: the aforementioned clothes (роба) that Ilya uses to work. Clothing motif.

foreign motif explanatory intratextuality
scab

Here meaning a hard top layer covering something.

explanatory
nomadic is your lot

Ilya curses his “незавидную […] участь” (unenviable lot/fate) not long before this (R175/E45).

intratextuality
He

God. She is wishing Ilya’s death.

character
ironwares

Pieces of metal.

explanatory
wouldn’t hide them dawns

Hiding dawns suggests being stuck in darkness, the twilight.

theme explanatory
cheater

Orina.

character
your bean

Ilya’s body is compared to the dry protective casing of the seeds of cereal grains.

character
vobla

Caspian roach. Animal motif.

motif
like the dolt at the mill who has lost all his wits as if someone hit him with a heavy sack

The same character will appear again at the end of chapter 9 (“the miller’s helper, a dimwit and spindle-legs”) (R218/E119).

intratextuality
mill

One more reference to mills contained in the book. Consider, for instance, R153/E7.

intratextuality
someone hit him with a heavy sack

Boguslawski literally translated the original Russian set expression (pyl’nym meshkom stebat’, hit with a dust bag; stebat’ iz-za ugla, hit from around the corner), meaning a stupid, insane weirdo.

phraseologism translation
jeremiad

A long literary serious invective of bitter lamentation on the state of society and its morals. The use of this term clashes with the general low register used by Ilya. The term is named after the prophet Jeremiah who wrote the Book of Jeremiah *and the *Book of Lamentations. Jeremiah predicted the downfall of the Kingdom of Judah.

explanatory register/style bible religion intertextuality
lift my walleye unto the sky

A reference to Psalm 121.

intertextuality bible religion
Mumbo-jumbo

According to Boguslawski, the original words “tutorki-matutorki” are “the nonsensical title of a Russian folk song popular in the 1950s and 1960s” (“Annotations” 239). Listen to a recording here.

music intertextuality
Sankt-Petersburg
location
clapsnaps

Mousetraps.

explanatory
main capital

Tautologic.

poetic device
crashbaret

A drinking establishment. Original Russia: кубаре (kubare). A mixture of kubarem (to fall head over heels) and the French “cabaret.” Customers, of course, will fall over and crash to the floor if they drink too much. The name of the establishment is literalized in this way. On Sokolov’s use of neologisms, see Brainina.

language neologism setting location
wing

Another animal (bird) comparison. Animal-human motif.

motif
fiendish witch

In the original, zlydni, demonic beings, spirits hostile to the living in the mythology of the Ukrainians and Belarusians.

translation folklore
hop and gallop

In the original, skok-poskok, a quotation from Korney Chukovsky’s “Skok-poskok, molodoy drozdok.” Read text in Russian here.

intertextuality translation
Itil

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

foreign language location setting
first mornin frosts

Morning frost, occurring in spring or fall before sunrise.

time
Gutenacht

German: Good night.

foreign
if the nap doesn’t happen

As in Note VIII.

intratextuality
mouse

Reference to the Eastern Slavic fairy tale about Ryaba the Hen, which will be directly mentioned further below. Read a version of the original here and an English translation here. Animal motif.

motif intertextuality folklore
the mistress ain’t large either

Sokolov suggests to interpret it on the basis of the expression “ne velik barin” (not a great gentleman): “this is a way of speaking about a person of modest importance, not important, not noble. For example, the secretary reminds her boss that someone has been waiting in the waiting room for an hour, and the boss replies: ‘He is not a great gentleman, he can wait.’ And here Ilya calls the mouse (female in Russian) not a great gentleman, because it is small indeed” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

language phraseologism
Fenist the bird

See the fairy tale “The Feather of Finist the Falcon” (or “Finist the Falcon”) collected by Aleksandr Afanas’yev. Read the original here and an English translation here. As Margaret Zhiolkowski points up, “much as the grinder [Ilya] is crippled by a train because his wife’s lovers tie him to the track, Fenist cuts his wings when his beloved’s jealous sisters fasten knives and needles to her windowstill. Yet Fenist does ultimately find marital bliss, while Il’ia loses his wife when she futilely attempts to rescue him” (414). Animal motif.

motif intertextuality folklore
speckled

Reference to “Ryaba the hen”, an Eastern Slavic fairy tale. Read a version of the original here and an English translation here. Animal motif.

intertextuality folklore motif
Somewhere, most likely, it is long

A reference to the concept of the “long nineteenth century” proposed by the historian Eric Hobsbawm to define the period between 1789 and 1914. By contrast, the XXth century has been defined as the “short century.”

time intertextuality
but not here, Beyond the Wolf

Life “beyond the Itil” is nasty, brutish, and short. There are many deaths in the novel, for animals and people alike.

explanatory structure
Beyond the Wolf

In the original, instead of indicating the territories that serve as setting for the novel as “Zavolzh’e” (Transvolga), the author creates this neologism (Transwolf-river) on the basis of his alternative spelling of the Volga River as “Volch’ia,” Wolf river.

translation location setting Russia
For reference: I don’t know about you, instigators, but we, grinders and wardens, consider Beyond the Wolf those places that lie across the Wolf River, regardless from which side you look

Ilya insists on the relativity of the perspective as well as on apparent objective considerations, such as geography. T. Baknina writes: “The introduction of Bruegel’s images into the artistic world of the novel is an extensions of the boundaries of the key images of Zaitilshchina. […] This wonderful phrase […] speaks to how the world Beyond the Volga is limitless” (183).

theme structure setting location
instigators

In the original Ilya uses the word for researchers (исследователи) instead of investigators (следователи).

translation language
Beyond the Wolf

In the original, instead of indicating the territories that serve as setting for the novel as “Zavolzh’e” (Transvolga), the author creates this neologism (Transwolf-river) on the basis of his alternative spelling of the Volga River as “Volch’ia,” Wolf river.

location setting Russia translation
lonesome babe

She will make several appearances throughout the novel and is associated with Orina.

character
Ilya

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality character folklore
morels

Edible mushrooms (Morchella).

explanatory
she’s started cravin, You see, somethin salty

She is presumably pregnant.

character explanatory
undoubtfully

Doubtlessly, undoubtedly.

language
impersonator

In the original Ilya uses the word “figurant” (a person involved in a criminal trial), instead of “figura” (figure), possibly suggesting that he is a “bad actor.”

translation language register/style
smeared with dirt

Boguslawski literally translated a Russian archaic phraseologism meaning to dishonor, ruin one’s reputation.

translation phraseologism
sorrel

According to Gretchen Scoble and Ann Field, “Sorrel grows in tapering spires of reddish flowers above spear-shaped leaves that change from green in the spring to a deep red in the late summer. Sorrel has always been well received in the kitchen, where its sour leaves add tang to soups and sauces. […] Sorrel bespeaks parental affection in the language of flowers” (75). Plant motif.

motif
horseradish

Plant motif.

motif
boots

D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif intertextuality
boots

D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif intertextuality
Intercession

October 14 (1, old calendar). In this day, according to folk tradition, fall and winter meet.

time Russia explanatory folklore
someone much more famous than we had suffered, recommendin we do the same

According to Ostanin, a reference to the proverb “Христос [Бог] терпел и нам велел” (Christ [God] suffered and made it our lot” (38).

intertextuality religion folklore
Intercession

October 14 (1, old calendar). In this day, according to folk tradition, fall and winter meet.

time Russia explanatory folklore
frosts harden all the mud

Another merging of opposites: dark and light.

theme
valenok

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

boot

intertextuality motif
figurelatively

Figuratively or relatively.

language
boot

intertextuality motif
valenok

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. intertextuality motif Russia
valenki

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. intertextuality motif Russia
defective

In the original instead of defitsit (deficit, shortage), Ilya creates a noun, defektiv (defect), from the adjective defektivny (defective). Boguslawski reflects this confusion through a substantivized adjective.

register/style neologism translation
we managed for two

To the reader of the original this expression is an evident variation of “soobrazhat’ na troikh” (literally, manage for three): to drink in company, sharing the costs of alcohol. The expression dates back to the Soviet times. Once again, the book touches upon the theme of drinking.

phraseologism translation theme
he’s missin this one and I the opposite

Ilya and his friend are both missing one leg each.

explanatory
sniffed each other out

Literally to recognize one another by the sniff (as dogs), that is to say, to start a good relationship. Once again Ilya is associated with animals’ behaviour. Animal-human motif.

register/style character motif
Two boots of leather flock together

Boguslawski translates the Russian set expression “dva sapoga - para” (two boots make a pair). The phraseologism (as elsewhere in the book) turns real as they both have only one leg. Furthermore, D.B. Johnson, writes: “The proverbial idea ‘two boots make a pair’ supports the suggestion that the two men are related, although the point is made more forcefully (and grotesquely) by their sharing (and stealing) a single set of footwear. It also hints at the intergrading of personalities so typical of the murky world between dog and wolf. The other function is more speculative. Both father and son are lame. They do not know each other. The son is destined to kill the father. It appears that they have both loved the same woman, i.e. the mentally defective girl who shares much of her past (including the slipper episode) with Orina, the wife and mother. The parallel to the Oedipus legend is striking: father and son are lame (cf. the etymologies of Laios and Oedipus), they do not recognize each other, the son kills the father, and loves (a version of) his mother” (“The Galoshes Manifesto”165). Shoe motif.

phraseologism structure translation character motif language
boots

D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

intertextuality motif
Where, as in the song, goes the right hoof, there the left claw follows

A variation of the saying “Kuda kon’ s kopytom, tuda i rak s kleshnyoi”: of someone who acts as if they were better or stronger than they actually are in order to imitate somebody. An echo of the two banks of the Volga resembling each other.

phraseologism translation
orphan lindens

Ostanin (38) suggests that these trees are situated in the park of a former orphanage (sirotsky priyut).

language motif
father’s orchard

Ostanin (38) intends “father’s orchard” as a synonym for kindergarten. Ilya’s potential son, Yakov, will be introduced soon after.

intratextuality
valenki

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

intertextuality motif Russia
Look, be so kind, into my stern eyes, look, perhaps, for the last time

Quotation from one of the most famous prison camp songs, written in the late 1940s “Etap na sever” (Step towards the North). Read the original here. Watch performance here.

intertextuality music
It is wonderful outside—our native land. Kinda mother, but strikingly sly, deceitful. In the beginnin, overall, it appears to be—land like land, only poor, with nothin in it. But after you’ve made yourself at home, looked more carefully—there’s everythin in it, except valenki

Russia, a “cunning” and “deceptive” “motherland”, is described as rich in its essence, although poor at first sight. Ilya uses similar wording at the beginning of chapter 6 (R189/E71). Mark Lipovetsky comments that “Russia is a figurative synonym for Orina, both as the mother who abandons her child (in relation to Yakov) and as an unfaithful lover (in relation to Ilya). Moreover, the author, like Ilya, longs for his beloved, tries to meet her and runs away from her, hates her and pities her” (Russian Postmodernist Fiction 143).

intratextuality Russia
valenki

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

intertextuality motif Russia
pediatric haunts

“Pediatric haunts” would align with Ostanin’s reading of “father’s orchard” as a reference to kindergarten (38).

intratextuality
frozen hill

Traditional winter pastime.

explanatory Russia
snow fortress

Traditional Russian winter pastime.

explanatory Russia
Pyotr Alexeich

Peter the Great (1672-1725).

Russia
in Botfortovo

As Ostanin suggests (38), in Botfortovo Ilya mixes up the term “botforty” (Peter the Great’s favorite boots), the last name of one of the Emperor’s close associates, François Le Fort (or Lefort; 1656-1699), and the Lefortovo district in Moscow, founded in 1699 and named after him. The narrator in chapter 9 does the same (R215/E115). D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif intratextuality language Russia intertextuality
with their cheeks, as the sayin goes, visible from the back

Set expression: a fat person.

phraseologism
They hurt, they laugh, and thru the pane their doctor shakes his fist in vain

Quote from Pushkin’s Onegin (chapter 5.II): in the original, it is “mama” who menaces at the window. Read the original here.

intertextuality
the leg of my pajamas flutters empty

Since Ilya is missing a leg.

explanatory
Lyusha

Diminutive form of Ilya.

register/style
Lyusha

Diminutive form of Ilya.

register/style
Alfeyev

Iakov Alfeev (James, son of Alphaeus) was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is also known as James the Less, or “the minor,” “the little,” “the lesser,” “the younger.” In the next chapter, Yakov will acquire a different last name, Palamakhterov: his changing last names may also be “justified” by the implied semantic link existing between his first name and the word “yakoby,” literally maybe, perhaps.

character bible language intertextuality religion
Yakov

Although appearing only now, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the only fictional author of the entire book. In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is “not fresh and not young”); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov plays a central role also in the structuring of the plot, as it is him who kills Ilya in revenge.

character structure
Ilyich

Yakov Alfeev’s patronymic suggests Ilya is his father. Yet, the suggestion is debatable. D.B. Johnson noted: “Yakov is Ilya’s son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (…). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) ‘marries’ a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (1984; 211-212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter’s dogs for a wolf and kills it. For a consideration of Sokolov’s mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova’s “Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov.”

character
they stuck like leaves from bathhouse twigs

Literally, these kids are annoying like birch twigs used in a Russian banya, a type of sauna, to improve circulation. Boguslawski literally translated this Russian set expression.

Russia phraseologism translation
And he was a poet, a versifier

Yakov is presumably also the author of the Notes.

intratextuality character
Sidor

The investigator for special cases Pozhilykh to whom Ilya is addressing his letter.

intratextuality character
Isidor

Ostanin notes that this is a reference to Isidore of Chios, a martyr killed by order of Decius (39). His feast day is May 14.

religion
they are picturesque

We can understand this hint literally (these poems come accompanied by pictures, drawings) or metaphorically (they are structured on depicted pictures, in an ekphrastic manner). Moreover, this is resonant with some chapters’ title, “Kartinki s vystavki,” Pictures from an Exhibition.

intratextuality explanatory structure
the poem about the homeless dog

A reference to Note XXXII, “Eclogue”: “Dog decided to stick there with me. / ’Twas considered homeless, however, / Rather fat it appeared to be.” (R270/E210).

intratextuality
Fomich

The investigator for special cases Pozhilykh to whom Ilya is addressing his letter.

character intratextuality
the night is fallin

So it’s again twilight time.

time theme
theater

As will be explained just further below, the “anatomichesky teatr” is here implied.

explanatory setting
under the number one

Address: house no. 1.

setting
hunchbacked

The image of humpbacked people and animals appears several times throughout the novel (R152, 168, 180, 184, 187, 189, 200, 217, 103, 268/E6, 61, 66, 69, 89, 208).

intratextuality
a former chapel with an amputated cross

This detail possibly witnesses of the Soviet epoch as time setting of the book. Since the setting is that of an hospital and a morgue, Ilya logically chooses the verb “to amputate.”

Russia time setting
cross

The cross is a crucial symbol in A School for Fools, more precisely in the story/parable titled “The Carpenter in the Desert” contained in it. As the story tells, the carpenter wonders: ‘Fine, I don’t have material to build a house, a carousel, or a crate, but I have two boards and one good nail’ (R115/E141). He then makes a cross out of these poor materials. Later on, some people come and ask him to help them crucify a man; at first, he refuses the idea, but then they persuade him successfully. As the crucified man is dying he decides to tell the carpenter his story, which echoes the carpenter’s. ‘You fool,’ he addresses the carpenter, ‘haven’t you understood yet there’s absolutely no difference between us, that you and I are one and the same man’ (R117–118/E143). In the end, the narrator says, ‘the carpenter died’ (R118/E144).

intertextuality intratextuality self-reference
anatomists

Being white, willows resemble doctors (here: pathologists) dressed in white coats.

explanatory
a sign with old-fashioned letters

This sign is presumably written according to the pre-reform alphabet (before 1918).

explanatory
artists

That is: dead people.

explanatory
orderly

A recurrent image also in A School for fools and in Sokolov’s own biography (he himself worked as a orderly).

self-reference author intertextuality
who took poison

The character Kaluga eats belladonna berries and dies from poisoning (R225/E132).

intratextuality character
who took poison, who burned from cancer, who got crushed, and who went simply out of stupidity

Death, like in previous and successive chapters (e.g. the ice skaters’ fate in ch. 1), continues to play a big role.

theme
non-advanced age

Young.

language
and the decay did not touch her body at all, unlike it does to many others. I dare to hope that the serafims were gardin her better

There is something saintly about her in this suggestion of incorruptibility.

religion
serafims

The highest ranked Christian angel class, the seraphim are best known from Isaiah 6:1–8: “In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord, high and exalted, seated on a throne; and the train of his robe filled the temple. Above him were seraphim, each with six wings: With two wings they covered their faces, with two they covered their feet, and with two they were flying. And they were calling to one another: ‘Holy, holy, holy is the Lord Almighty; the whole earth is full of his glory.’” They are also mentioned in Alexander Pushkin’s seminal 1826 poem “The Prophet”: “Tormented by a spiritual thirst, / I stumbled through a gloomy waste, / And there a six-winged seraph / Appeared before me at the crossroad.” Read the original and this English translation here. Later mentioned in chapter 6 (R195/E80).

religion bible intertextuality intratextuality
Orya

The girl’s fate reminds Ilya of Orina.

character
Orya

Diminutive form of Orina. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Ilya

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality character folklore
Unhappiness is when there is no happiness, and happiness, Orya, is when there’s no unhappiness

Ilya is a bit tautologic. This phrase is repeated also in chapter 8 (R205/E97).

intratextuality character
Orya

Diminutive form of Orina. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character theme intertextuality intratextuality
governmental pure grain

According to Ostanin, medicinal spirits (39).

explanatory
Tartar

In Greek mythology, Tartarus is the abyss where wicked people are tormented and suffer, and where souls are judged after death. In the Middle Ages, the most remote corners of the earth started to be called Tartarus. It should be kept in mind that Sokolov himself worked in a morgue for some time in 1961 after completing school.

explanatory author
free firewater

According to Ostanin, medicinal spirits (39).

explanatory
Alfeyev

Iakov Alfeev (James, son of Alphaeus) was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is also known as James the Less, or “the minor,” “the little,” “the lesser,” “the younger.” In the next chapter, Yakov will acquire a different last name, Palamakhterov: his changing last names may also be “justified” by the implied semantic link existing between his first name and the word “yakoby,” literally maybe, perhaps.
