character language intertextuality religion bible
Alfeyev, Yakov Ilyich

The word order indicates the bureaucratese.

register/style
Yakov

Although appearing only now, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the only fictional author of the entire book. In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is “not fresh and not young”); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov plays a central role also in the structuring of the plot, as it is him who kills Ilya in revenge.

character structure
Ilyich

Yakov Alfeev’s patronymic suggests Ilya is his father. Yet, the suggestion is debatable. D.B. Johnson noted: “Yakov is Ilya’s son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (…). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) ‘marries’ a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (1984; 211-212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter’s dogs for a wolf and kills it. For a consideration of Sokolov’s mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova’s “Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov.”

character
war rumors

Quote from Matthew 24:6.

intertextuality religion bible
To the positions, he recalls, a girl saw the soldier off

Quote from Mikhail Isakovsky’s poem “Ogonyok” (1942), made popular as a song. Read the original here. Indeed, the song depicts a couple being parted by war, but the thought of her distant love is enough for him to bravely serve against the enemy for the “Soviet motherland.”

intertextuality music
fascines

A bundle of brushwood or other similar material used to strengthen a structure or to create a path. They are frequently used around water. Plant motif. Perhaps also an echo of “fascist” given the WWII theme.

motif sound play explanatory
a loquacious rhymester

Oblique allusion to the military march song “Marsh Budyonnogo” (1920). Read the original here. Listen to it here.

intertextuality music
Yakov

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
Ilyich

Yakov Alfeev’s patronymic implies that Ilya is his father. However, this reading is debatable. D.B. Johnson notes: “Yakov is Ilya’s son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (…). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) ‘marries’ a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211–212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter’s dogs for a wolf and attacks it. After the hunters steal his crutches, Yakov returns to murder the dogs. For a consideration of Sokolov’s mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova’s “Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov.”

character intertextuality
soldier’s walkin, okeydokey, to the war

A counting-out rhyme, which serves also as the title of a famous and successful Soviet movie about World War II, released in 1976. In English it is known as “One-Two, Soldiers Were Going…”. The film poster is Read the rhyme here.

intertextuality
affidavits of inability to work

Document attesting they are unable to work. The name, however, is an ironic variation: in the original, instead of “bulletin’ netrudosposobnosti” we read “belyutni netrudovitosti”; Boguslawski tries to render this in translation through the non-standard use of “affidavits” and “inability” (instead of “incapacity”).

translation register/style irony
Yakov

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
were figures

Boguslawski translates here Ilya’s dropping of a couple letters from the verb “фигурировать” (to figure).

translation language
Alfeyev

Iakov Alfeev (James, son of Alphaeus) was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is also known as James the Less, or “the minor,” “the little,” “the lesser,” “the younger.” In the next chapter, Yakov will acquire a different last name, Palamakhterov: his changing last names may also be “justified” by the implied semantic link existing between his first name and the word “yakoby,” literally maybe, perhaps.

character intertextuality bible religion language
Ilya

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality character folklore
were figures

Boguslawski translates here Ilya’s dropping of a couple letters from the verb “фигурировать” (to figure).

translation language
Mayday

Boguslawski translates the original “polundra,” meaning “Take care of yourself.” The term was originally linked with sailing, marines, navy.

language translation
Yakov

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
Ilyich

Yakov Alfeev’s patronymic implies that Ilya is his father. However, this reading is debatable. D.B. Johnson notes: “Yakov is Ilya’s son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (…). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) ‘marries’ a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211–212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter’s dogs for a wolf and attacks it. After the hunters steal his crutches, Yakov returns to murder the dogs. For a consideration of Sokolov’s mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova’s “Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov.”

character intertextuality
Alfeyev

Iakov Alfeev (James, son of Alphaeus) was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is also known as James the Less, or “the minor,” “the little,” “the lesser,” “the younger.” In the next chapter, Yakov will acquire a different last name, Palamakhterov: his changing last names may also be “justified” by the implied semantic link existing between his first name and the word “yakoby,” literally maybe, perhaps.

character intertextuality bible religion language
Alfeyev

Iakov Alfeev (James, son of Alphaeus) was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is also known as James the Less, or “the minor,” “the little,” “the lesser,” “the younger.” In the next chapter, Yakov will acquire a different last name, Palamakhterov: his changing last names may also be “justified” by the implied semantic link existing between his first name and the word “yakoby,” literally maybe, perhaps.

religion language character intertextuality bible
from what kind of a highway such irrepressible enthusiasts had come about

Boguslawski writes: “A combined reference to the famous highway Shosse Entuziastov (Enthusiasts’ Highway) in Moscow and to ‘otkuda est’ poshla russkaia zemlia’ (from whence had the Russian land come), a part of the opening sentence of the twelfth-century Russian chronicle Povest’ vremennykh let (The Tale of Bygone Years)” (“Annotations” 240). Read the original here and an English translation here.

intertextuality Russia
speckled

Reference to “Ryaba the hen”, an Eastern Slavic fairy tale. Read a version of the original here and an English translation here. Animal motif.

intertextuality motif folklore
Alfeyev

Iakov Alfeev (James, son of Alphaeus) was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is also known as James the Less, or “the minor,” “the little,” “the lesser,” “the younger.” In the next chapter, Yakov will acquire a different last name, Palamakhterov: his changing last names may also be “justified” by the implied semantic link existing between his first name and the word “yakoby,” literally maybe, perhaps.

character intertextuality bible religion language
the cooer did not peck Petrukha on his temple

Ilya repeats a sentence he used at the beginning of the chapter.

intratextuality
cooer

A pigeon used to transport messages (homing pigeon). Animal motif.

motif
nappin book

Ostanin (41) suggests this is a book of fairy tales to be read to children before sleep. Ilya goes back to the moment he introduced this book (when he could not sleep at night), closing (for the moment) the digression.

intratextuality explanatory
speckled

Reference to “Ryaba the hen”, an Eastern Slavic fairy tale. Read a version of the original here and an English translation here. Animal motif.

intertextuality folklore motif
Allah

The Arabic word for God. Likely related to the fact that “Itil’” is the Turkic name of the Volga. It is also be found in the Tatar language, and most Tatars are Muslims.

religion foreign
Itil

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location language foreign setting
You are befuddled again

An apparent allusion to the reader’s experience of reading Ilya’s letter, not just that of Pozhilykh.

self-reference
Ilya

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality character folklore
fable

Ilya is indeed paraphrasing “Ryaba the hen”, an Eastern Slavic fairy tale. Read a version of the original here and an English translation here. Animal motif.

explanatory folklore intertextuality motif
But why, I’d like to know, for what reason did they create the above parable at all, what is, I am askin, the point of this once-upon-a-time tale

Ilya wishes (possibly ironically) to understand what is the sense, the meaning of such a fairy tale, whether it is a parable carrying any meaning at all, or not. In a sense, this is what the reader may wonder reading Sokolov’s novel and failing to grasp its plot, structure, and levels of interpretation. Possibly, this is a (Nabokovian) provocation for readers who search for meaning in any literary work. Before agreeing to appear in Maxim Gureev’s documentary film about him, Sokolov asked the director whether he had a script prepared. When Gureev replied in the negative, Sokolov responded positively: “Plot… That side of literature never appealed to me. Plot is a contrived thing. Plot is used to sell something. For me it’s important how language works, the linguistic dance of its own kind. If I was born in a different time, in a different place, in a different family, I would have become a composer, because is one of the forms of music” (Gureev 165–166).

explanatory character intratextuality structure self-reference
parable

An important parable is contained in the fifth chapter of Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, and is entitled “The Carpenter in the Desert.” According to many scholars, this text represents a key moment not only within the plot of this specific novel but for Sokolov’s art in general: Ludmilla Litus affirms that “this parable […] provides an important clue to understanding the work as a whole” (“Aesopian Language” 129); Leiderman and Lipovetksy write that “the central episode of this chapter, Saul’s parable of the carpenter […] is important above all because it metamorphoses categories that previously belonged to the polar worldviews presented in A School for Fools: creator and executioner, bird and victim, executioner and victim. Creator — executioner — bird — victim form here a certain undivided flowing whole” (Russkaia literatura dvadtsatogo veka 406); Margaret Ziolkowski notices that “like a biblical parable, […] it asserts that corruption constitutes self-betrayal and that a dedication to lofty aesthetic aims does not afford protection against surrender to crass temptation […]. his avian guise provides a vision of the carpenter’s true spiritual essence” (411). Mario Caramitti in his doctoral dissertation explains that through this parable “Sokolov expresses his theory of art in the most complete manner. Sokolov’s carpenter, after briefly transforming into a bird, kills himself by volunteering to crucify another carpenter, in exchange for the tools he needs to continue working. In essence, master and prophet annihilate each other in the presence of insurmountable impediments external to art. If we then consider that in Palisandriia there is even a ‘назаретский плотник’ (a carpenter from Nazareth), the field of ambivalence comes to fully involve not only the inspired artist and the craftsman, but also the divine and the human, co-present and conflicting. The artist, like Christ, is both God and man, he is both victim and executioner of himself, and like Christ he is the absolute arbiter of his own destiny, the master and responsible for his own art, whatever the external circumstances that influence him. The artistic vocation reconfirms itself as an energy that is difficult to control and has disturbing implications. The carpenter protests, ‘Но я мастер, а не палач’ (But I’m a master craftsman and not an executioner). But blind faith in the art nonetheless leads him to the execrable choice: ‘Ты ведь – плотник, а плотник обязан забивать гвозди, это дело его жизни’ (You’re a carpenter and carpenters are supposed to hammer nails, it’s their mission in life). The role in the parable played by the men who in exchange for wood and nails ask the carpenter to crucify himself (through his fellow man) remains to be defined. On the one hand, one might tend to associate them with the no less ambiguous Those Who Came of the first chapter of the novel, thus keeping them in the realm of personal mythology. On the other hand, as Ludmila Litus (“Aesopian Language” 128–132) shows with discreetly convincing arguments, they could be emissaries of the totalitarian society, which allows the artist to work only if they accept the compromise. In this case, given the desert setting, the association with diabolic temptation would also be immediate” (“Strategie” 153).

intertextuality self-reference theme
once-upon-a-time tale

Vladimir Bondarenko calls the novel a “collection of Russian folklore, beyond any plot” (529).

structure folklore
Beyond the Wolf

In the original, instead of indicating the territories that serve as setting for the novel as “Zavolzh’e” (Transvolga), the author creates this neologism (Transwolf-river) on the basis of his alternative spelling of the Volga River as “Volch’ia,” Wolf river.

translation location setting Russia
ain’t the feeble old people livin right there

Ilya is conflating “real life” with the parable’s plot, in a sense thus mixing up metaphor with reality, as is common throughout the novel.

explanatory structure
frog princesses

Russian fairy tail of the Frog Princess. Read a version of the Russian original here and an English translation here. Animal-human motif.

intertextuality motif folklore
a broken trough

Reference to the Russian fairy tale, written by A.S. Pushkin “The Tale of the Fisherman and the Fish” (1835). Read the Russian original here and an English translation here. Animal motif.

intertextuality motif
Fomich

The investigator for special cases Pozhilykh to whom Ilya is addressing his letter.

character intertextuality
a cabbage, a goat, and a wolf

Reference to the “wolf, goat and cabbage puzzle”, which dates back to at least the 9th century and is popular in many cultures. Read it here. Animal motif.

intertextuality motif folklore
Yakov

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
Ilyich

Yakov Alfeev’s patronymic implies that Ilya is his father. However, this reading is debatable. D.B. Johnson notes: “Yakov is Ilya’s son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (…). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) ‘marries’ a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211–212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter’s dogs for a wolf and attacks it. After the hunters steal his crutches, Yakov returns to murder the dogs. For a consideration of Sokolov’s mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova’s “Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov.”

character intertextuality
valenki

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

intertextuality motif Russia
situcraption

Boguslawski creates this neologism, meaning “crappy situation” (“Annotations” 240), to render the original colloquial “situyovina” (shituation, bad situation).

neologism translation register/style
Friggin-frigged-frig

In the original, instead of profanities and other insults, only initials are indicated. The “ë” openly refers to a curse word (meaning something close to “damn”).

translation register/style
Yakov

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
valenki

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

intertextuality motif Russia
galoshes

D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif intertextuality
side-warmer

In the original Russian, it is a dated word meaning February. It will be mentioned again in chapter 14 (another chapter by Ilya). The word derives from the terms “бок” (side) and “греть” (to warm). As Boguslawski translates it, “side-warmer,” meaning a shift in weather that will warm your sides. A reference to St. Sidor Bokogrei, whose day is celebrated on May 14/27. He was given this name, because it was said that bitterly cold northern winds would stop blowing on this date. Likewise, swifts and swallows would fly to Sidor with the approach of warm weather. However, people caution against taking the appearance of the first bird as a sure sign of the cold’s departure, similar to the following clause. Read his saint’s life here. The addressee of Ilya’s letter is, of course, Sidor (Fomich Pozhilykh).

time translation register/style religion intratextuality
at the front I served as another Yakov

Another instance of characters’ identities blurring.

character
Yakov

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
Pig-Breedin and Youth

An ironic allusion to Soviet newspapers and magazines. In the original the word “molodyozh” (youth) is accented incorrectly (the vowel “yo” / “ë” is always accented).

language Russia irony
valenki

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

intertextuality motif Russia
pit

The morgue was previously defined as a “theater,” so the lower floor of the hospital is consequently called the “(orchestra) pit” (in the original, it says parterre).

language setting translation
chlamyses

A cloak in Ancient Greece. Clothing motif.

explanatory motif foreign
Ivan

Ivan/Vanya/Vanechka. This is the name of the male nurse at the hospital where Ilya is treated (R183/E59). However, another Ivan, a “glass man” who chokes to death, appears in the Note XXXI (R268–269/E209). The name Ivan (John) has Hebrew origins and means “God is gracious.” In the Christian tradition, it is linked with the figures of John the Apostle and John the Baptist.

character intratextuality intertextuality religion bible
How many kindhearted souls are scattered around our damp cellars!

A possible hint to the underground scene in Soviet times.

explanatory
Uncle Vanechka

Ivan/Vanya/Vanechka. An allusion to Chekhov’s Uncle Vanya. Read the original Russian here and English translation here. Since the morgue is described as a theater, it is not surprising that the nurse is an “uncle Vanya.”Another Ivan, a “glass man” who chokes to death, appears in the Note XXXI (R268–269/E209). The name Ivan (John) has Hebrew origins and means “God is gracious.” In the Christian tradition, it is linked with the figures of John the Apostle and John the Baptist.

intertextuality character intratextuality religion bible
galife

A type of trousers, typical for the army. Named after Gaston Alexandre Auguste, Marquis de Galliffet, a French general. Clothing motif.

foreign motif
clerk’s top hat with a tilt

The same style of hat is mentioned in Note VIII (R172/E39). Clothing motif.

motif intratextuality
lapserdak

A long coat, typical for Polish and Galician Jews. Clothing motif.

foreign motif
Alfeyev

Iakov Alfeev (James, son of Alphaeus) was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is also known as James the Less, or “the minor,” “the little,” “the lesser,” “the younger.” In the next chapter, Yakov will acquire a different last name, Palamakhterov: his changing last names may also be “justified” by the implied semantic link existing between his first name and the word “yakoby,” literally maybe, perhaps.

character intertextuality bible religion language
antique moiré

French: moire antique. Made of moire fabric. Clothing motif.

foreign motif
zhorzhet

Georgette, wool fabric created by weaving twisted fine wool fibers together. Clothing motif.

motif explanatory
hop, don’t stop, granny sowed the peas for crop

Folk tune. Read the original here.

intertextuality music folklore
the storm’s turbulence

According to Ostanin (42), a quotation from Nadezhda Pavlovich’s poem “Beregom, beregom, s razbegu…”. Read the original here.

intertextuality
Это Петр

For a detailed analysis of this chapter’s opening scene and its connections to the novel’s meta levels, see Mariya Donska’s “Poisk bukv.”

explanatory
Петр

In the Gospels, Peter (and his brother Andrew) was invited by Jesus to become a “fisher of men.” See for instance Matthew 4:19.

В Евангелиях Петр (и его брат Андрей) призваны Иисусом быть “ловцами человеков”. Например, в Послании от Матфея 4:19.

character intertextuality bible religion
грамотей

Colloquial: smart aleck.

Разговорное: умник, всезнайка.

register/style
слободской

In ancient Russia, a sloboda referred to a settlement found in Povolzhye, Central Russia, Belarus, or Ukraine. The term is derived from the word for freedom. These tax-free settlements came to an end in the early eighteenth century when the practice was abolished and the settlements became regular villages. Often these suburbs were eventually subsumed by nearby cities. Today, sloboda refers to a rural locality in various oblasts. Sokolov attests that a Sloboda can be found by the Volga River in Konakovskii raion (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

В Древней Руси, поселение в Поволжье, Центральной России, Беларуси или Украине. Образовано от слова “свобода”. Подобные поселения, свободные от повинностей, были упразднены в начале XVIII века и стали обыкновенными деревнями. Зачастую, пригородные районы поглощались близлежащими городами. В современном языке, “слобода” в разных областях относится к населенному пункту в сельской местности.

Russia explanatory location
отошел я на промысел

He finds seasonal jobs.

Занимается сезонной работой.

explanatory
фурычит

Colloquial: function, work, do its thing.

Разговорное: работать, функционировать, быть в рабочем состоянии.

register/style
потьмах

Dated: darkness.

Устаревшее: темнота.

register/style
птичьего зрения

Not all birds can boast a sharp sight. Usually the parallel is made with the falcon’s or eagle’s eye (“sokolinoe / orlinoe zrenie”). Once again, birds in general play a role in Ilya’s comprehension of his own reality.

Не все птицы могут похвастаться острым зрением. Обычно проводится параллель к соколиному/орлиному зрению. В очередной раз, птицы в целом играют важную роль в восприятии реальности Ильей.

explanatory symbol motif
Петру

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign intratextuality religion
Павел

Biblical reference, see also the character Pavl/Saul in A School for Fools.

Библейская отсылка (в “Школе для дураков”, Павел/Савл).

intertextuality character self-reference
племяш

Colloquial: nephew.

Разговорное: племянник.

register/style
письмо ему треугольное

A letter folder up by a soldier into a triangle without an envelope and mailed for free. During WWII, soldiers had to send mail this way due to shortages.

Письмо, которое складывалось солдатом в треугольник и отправлялось бесплатно без конверта. Во время Второй мировой войны, из-за нехватки ресурсов солдаты были вынуждены таким образом обмениваться почтой.

explanatory
турман

A pigeon used to transport messages (homing pigeon). Animal motif.

Голубь, используемый для передачи сообщений (почтовый голубь).

explanatory motif
постоялый двор

Historically, an inexpensive peasant hotel used for overnight lodgings and food. Also known as стоялый, постоялый, заезжий, выезжий двор, подворье, кабак, and корчма.

Исторически, тип недорогой крестьянской гостиницы с ночлегом и пищей. Также известен как стоялый, постоялый, заезжий, выезжий двор, подворье, кабак или корчма.

explanatory location Russia
Петр

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character intratextuality foreign religion
Петр с отдельными сторожами охотничьими винище употребляет немилосердно, в ко́зны режется, песни затеял шуметь

Petr leads a “regular” life by the Volga, as described elsewhere in the book: drinking, playing games, and singing/dancing.

structure character setting location
винище

A derogatory term for wine. Alcohol theme.

Пренебрежительное название для вина. Тема алкоголя.

register/style theme
немилосердно

Colloquial: a lot.

Разговорное: очень много.

register/style
ко́зны режется

Bones (бабки) — a game in which players throw dice a predetermined number of times and compare their totals.

Бабки — игра, в которой игроки бросают игральные кости определенное количество раз и сравнивают выпавшие значения.

explanatory
затеял

Colloquial: to take up, start.

Разговорное: начать, предпринять.

register/style
Турман

A pigeon used to transport messages (homing pigeon). Animal motif.

explanatory motif
Турман Петра в темя клюет

According to Ostanin, a reference to Alexander Pushkin’s “Tale of the Golden Cockerel”: “Встрепенулся, клюнул в темя” (34). Read the original here. Read a translation here. Animal motif.

Согласно Останину, отсылка к “Сказке о золотом петушке” А. Пушкина: “Встрепенулся, клюнул в темя” (34). Прочитать оригинал можно здесь. Прочитать английский перевод можно здесь.

intertextuality motif
Петра

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign religion intratextuality
ты, Петр, пить пей, да дело разумей

According to Ostanin, a reference to Ivan Krylov’s 1808 fable “Musicians” (34). In Krylov’s poem one of the interlocutors comments that the musicians invited by his neighbor are very bad at singing, and the fact that they do not drink and behave well is not a justification for their musical incompetence. Read the original and an English translation here. Alcohol theme.

Согласно Останину, отсылка к басне И. Крылова “Музыканты” (1808): “А я скажу: по мне уж лучше пей, / Да дело разумей” (34). Прочитать оригинал и английский перевод басни можно здесь.

intertextuality music theme
Петр

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character foreign intratextuality religion
Петр, пить пей, да дело разумей. Петр письмо берет, распечатывает, а в нем написано

Alliteration (p).

Аллитерация (р).

sound stylistic device
пить пей, да дело разумей

Rhyme.

Рифма.

rhyme
Петр

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character intratextuality religion foreign
Петр письмо берет, распечатывает, а в нем написано что-то

Ilya will present a letter from Pyotr to Pavel in chapter 14 (R257/E190).

intratextuality
дрозжи

A misspelling of дрожжи (yeast) (per Dal, a dialectical variant). As Mario Caramitti noted in his doctoral dissertation (2001), Krylobyl represents an hypostasis of the poet Drozhzhin (recalled here through the misspelled “yeast”), the first Russian translator of Rilke, who lived on an island later on submerged by the Volga, situated in front of the little house Sokolov lived in during his time passed at Bezborodovo. When Ivan Podshivalov brings up Khlebnikov in an interview, Sokolov responds: “But you see, phonetics is the yeast, the fermenting agent of language. I start with a sound; sound is like a grain from which everything else grows. It’s impossible to speak about phonetics separately from meaning” (Podshivalov, “A Conversation” 357).

Неправильное написание слова “дрожжи”. (по Далю, диалектический вариант написания). Как замечает в докторской диссертации Марио Караматти (2001), Крылобыл представляет собой воплощение поэта Дрожжина (упомянут здесь через неправильное написание слова “дрожжи”), первого переводчика Рилке на русский. Дрожжин жил на острове, позже затопленным Волгой, расположенной напротив небольшого дома Соколова, где тот жил в период Безбородово.

language register/style intertextuality location self-reference
надеюсь пока что, что

Cataphora.

Катафора.

stylistic device rhythm
на продувное фуфу

Colloquial (на фуфу): carelessly, any which way.

Разговорное (на фуфу): халатно, безалаберно, лишь бы как.

register/style phraseologism
продувное

Colloquial: cunning craft.

Разговорное: обман, лукавство, надувательство.

register/style
слезно

Colloquial: desiring to appease.

Разговорное: стремящийся разжалобить кого-л.

register/style
Петр

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character intratextuality foreign religion
кубарэ

Unusual (and mockingly foreign) word. It may derive from the word “kubar’”, informally used by students of the naval academy to define a ship cabin.

Необычное (и мнимо-иностранное) слово, наверное от разговорного морского термина “кубарь”, каюта.

foreign neologism location setting
помогите советом, уж гибну я

An3. Dactylic ending.

Ан3. Дактилическое окончание.

metrical pattern
Павелом

Incorrect spelling, suggesting Ilya’s illiteracy (should be Павлом).

register/style
Городнище

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

Главное место действия романа: вымышленный город на берегу Волги, также называется Городнищи. Название получено в результате сочетания слов “город” и “нищий”. Таким образом, Городнищи — город нищих. О. Матич пишет: “Если Школа для дураков была написана в противовес молодежной прозе, следующий роман Соколова, Между собакой и волком можно расценивать как ответ автора на деревенскую прозу, модное литературное направление семидесятых” (Matich “Sasha Sokolov” 310). В. Крейд замечает, что Городнище, барачный город нищих и воров, напоминает “Анти-Китеж” (Китеж — мифический город в русском фольклоре, в который попадают только чистые сердцем). В Городнище, однако, воры грабят нищих, и нищие попрошайничают у грабителей (Kreid “Zaitil’shchina” 213). Согласно Джонсону, Городнище — обитель живых, в то время как мертвые населяют противоположный берег реки, в Быдогощах (Johnson “Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Джонсон также цитирует самого Соколова: “Соколов замечает, что название города является помесью развратного города XVIII века Городни, описанного А. Н. Радищевым в Путешествии из Петербурга в Москву и близлежащего города Городище. Таким образом, временные слои XVI века, XVIII века и мифического настоящего накладываются друг на друга — типичный роману прием” (217).

location intertextuality setting folklore theme
покупать, не то продавать

An echo of the beginning of the chapter.

Отголосок начала главы.

sound play intratextuality
по смерть меня командировать выгодно

Sokolov explains: “A person who is sent somewhere with a task and does not return for a long time can be said a good one to be sent to catch death (khorosho ego za smert’ju posylat’). That is, he is a person of slow action, not quick on his feet, not a swift walker. Pyotr is simply paraphrasing this expression: komandirovat’ (to command) = posylat’ (to send), vygodno (advantageous) = khorosho (good), po (by) = za (for). In the village they say: ‘idu po vodu’ (I go by water), not ‘za vodoi’ (for water), ‘idu po griby’ (I go by mushrooms), not ‘za gribami’ (for mushrooms) and, of course, ‘po smart’’ (by death), not ‘za smert’ju’ (for death). This is advantageous to the one who wants to send him, Pyotr, to catch death: Pyotr will bring it not very soon, the advantage for the one who sends him will be that he will live longer because of Pyotr’s slowness” (personal communication, August 21, 2023).

Соколов объясняет: “О человеке, которого послали куда-то с каким-то заданием и он долго не возвращается, могут сказать: его за смертью посылать хорошо. То есть это человек медленного действия, не скорый на ногу, не быстроход. Петр просто перифразирует это выражение: командировать = посылать, выгодно = хорошо, по = за. В деревне говорят: иду по воду, а не за водой, иду по грибы, а не за грибами и, конечно, по смерть, а не за смертью. Выгодно тому, кто захочет его, Петра, послать за смертью: Петр приведет или привезет ее очень не скоро, выгода посылающего будет состоять в том, что он из-за медлительности Петра проживет дольше” (личная переписка, 21 августа 2023).

language phraseologism register/style
нету сейчас ни товару, ни денег

Dak4. Dactylic ending.

Дак4. Дактилическое окончание.

metrical pattern
дрозжей

A misspelling of дрожжи (yeast) (per Dal, a dialectical variant). As Mario Caramitti noted in his doctoral dissertation (2001), Krylobyl represents an hypostasis of the poet Drozhzhin (recalled here through the misspelled “yeast”), the first Russian translator of Rilke, who lived on an island later on submerged by the Volga, situated in front of the little house Sokolov lived in during his time passed at Bezborodovo. This event is later recalled in Note XXVI (R238/E154). When Ivan Podshivalov brings up Khlebnikov in an interview, Sokolov responds: “But you see, phonetics is the yeast, the fermenting agent of language. I start with a sound; sound is like a grain from which everything else grows. It’s impossible to speak about phonetics separately from meaning” (Podshivalov, “A Conversation” 357).

Неправильное написание слова “дрожжи”. (по Далю, диалектический вариант написания). Как замечает в докторской диссертации Марио Караматти (2001), Крылобыл представляет собой воплощение поэта Дрожжина (упомянут здесь через неправильное написание слова “дрожжи”), первого переводчика Рилке на русский. Дрожжин жил на острове, позже затопленным Волгой, расположенной напротив небольшого дома Соколова, где тот жил в период Безбородово. Это событие позже упоминается в Записке XXVI (R238/E154).

register/style language location intertextuality intratextuality self-reference
Теребит

Colloquial: to pull lightly, with small pinches; to yank out, pluck out (down, feathers).

Разговорное: дёргать слегка, мелкими щипками; выдёргивать, вырывать (пух, перья).

register/style
Теребит

Colloquial: to pull lightly, with small pinches; to pull out, pull out (fluff, feathers).

Разговорное: дёргать слегка, мелкими щипками; выдёргивать, вырывать (пух, перья).

register/style
с того берега

In the world of Between Dog and Wolf, the exact and relative locations of various places along the Volga remain ambiguous, much as time and character shift constantly. An echo of “с которого бы берега ни соблюдать” (regardless from which side [shore] you look) (R178/E50). Also, a possible reference to Alexander Hertzen’s From the Other Shore. Read the original here and an English translation here.

location intratextuality intertextuality
мол

Colloquial: he says (particle used to denote reported speech).

Разговорное: говорит (частица для передачи чужой речи).

register/style
дрозжей

A misspelling of дрожжи (yeast) (per Dal, a dialectical variant). As Mario Caramitti noted in his doctoral dissertation (2001), Krylobyl represents an hypostasis of the poet Drozhzhin (recalled here through the misspelled “yeast”), the first Russian translator of Rilke, who lived on an island later on submerged by the Volga, situated in front of the little house Sokolov lived in during his time passed at Bezborodovo. When Ivan Podshivalov brings up Khlebnikov in an interview, Sokolov responds: “But you see, phonetics is the yeast, the fermenting agent of language. I start with a sound; sound is like a grain from which everything else grows. It’s impossible to speak about phonetics separately from meaning” (Podshivalov, “A Conversation” 357).

Неправильное написание слова “дрожжи”. (по Далю, диалектический вариант написания). Как замечает в докторской диссертации Марио Караматти (2001), Крылобыл представляет собой воплощение поэта Дрожжина (упомянут здесь через неправильное написание слова “дрожжи”), первого переводчика Рилке на русский. Дрожжин жил на острове, позже затопленным Волгой, расположенной напротив небольшого дома Соколова, где тот жил в период Безбородово.

intertextuality location language register/style self-reference
дрозжей браговарных

The characters are hoping to use the yeast to produce alcohol, which explains why they are so desperate in its absence. Alcohol theme.

theme explanatory
изъять

Literary: to take out.

Книжное: забрать.

register/style
жэ-букву

A reference to the missing letter zhe in the word дрожжи (yeast), misspelled as дрозжи. Boguslawski suggests that the “significance of the letter Zh depends less on its being a part of the word drozzhi (yeast; pronounced drozhzhi), but more on being the initial letter of the words zhizn’ (life) and zhenshchina (woman), two mysteries the narrators try to clarify and explain throughout the novel” (“Annotations” 238). When Ivan Podshivalov brings up Khlebnikov in an interview, Sokolov responds: “But you see, phonetics is the yeast, the fermenting agent of language. I start with a sound; sound is like a grain from which everything else grows. It’s impossible to speak about phonetics separately from meaning” (Podshivalov, “A Conversation” 357). The letter Ж belongs to the early Cyrillic alphabet, derived from Cyril’s Glagolitic letters. In this alphabet letters had a “name” (the very term “alphabet,” azbuka, derives from the first two letters, A – az, and B – buky), and Ж is called живѣ́те, the imperative of the verb “to live,” zhiti). There was no sound (and therefore no grapheme) in Greek or Latin, so this letter was created “from scratch” by Cyril (or possibly derived from Coptic or Semitic). According to one account, Ж may also be derived from the Christogram of Jesus Christ.

Отсылка к недостающей букве “ж” в слове “дрожжи”. Богуславский предполагает, что “важность буквы “ж” заключается не столько в ее причастности к слову “дрожжи”, но в том, что это первая буква слов “жизнь” и “женщина”, двух тайн, которые пытаются понять и объяснить оба рассказчика на протяжении всего романа (“Аннотации” 238). Когда И. Подшивалов упоминает Хлебникова в интервью, Соколов отвечает: “Видите ли, фонетика — это дрожжи, ферментирующий агент языка. Я начинаю со звука; звук подобен семени, из которого произрастает все остальное. Невозможно рассуждать о фонетике, отделив ее от значения” (Podshivalov, “A Conversation” 357).

language
раздобыть

Colloquial: to obtain, to get, usually with difficulty.

Разговорное: добыть, достать, обычно с трудом.

register/style
заколодило

Low/colloquial: to delay, stump, cause a delay.

Разговорное: создать помеху, вызвать задержку, застрять.

register/style
просветителям

In this discussion of various letters, Ilya alludes to Saints Cyril and Methodius, known as the “славянские просветители” (Slavic enlighteners). Of course, there’s a certain degree of irony in their being compared to the fathers of the Slavic alphabet.

В этом разговоре о буквах Илья упоминает святых Кирилла и Мефодия, известных как “славянские просветители”. Несомненно, в их сравнении с отцами славянского алфавита присутствует некоторая ирония.

explanatory irony
Петр

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character intratextuality foreign religion
виселицы

Pyotr suggests that the letter г (g) resembles the gallows.

По мнению Петра, буква “г” напоминает виселицу. Изображено ниже:

explanatory language
потому что на виселице эту букву и выговоришь одну: гэ да гэ

Because on the gallows people can only make strangled sounds. Here, Peter reflects on the arbitrariness of writing and alphabets in general (a topic of linguistic debate, see Saussure’s reasoning about the arbitrary connection between the signified and the signifier), linking graphemes and phonemes in the most logical (for him, at least) manner. This is another confirmation of how significant a role language plays in the novel. This event is later recalled in Note XXVI (R238/E154).

Потому что на виселице люди могут издавать только сдавленные звуки. Здесь, Петр размышляет о произвольности письменности и алфавитов в целом (тема лингвистических дебатов, см. рассуждение Соссюра о произольной связи между означаемым и означающим), связывая графемы и фонемы в наиболее логической (для него, по крайней мере) манере. Это еще одно подтверждение тому, насколько значительную роль в романе играет язык.

explanatory language theme intratextuality
Дэ — как дом

The letter д (d) is said to resemble a house in shape.

Буква “д”, по словам рассказчика, напоминает дом.

explanatory language
бэ — как вэ почти, вэ же почти как бэ

Ostanin (35) notes that in Chapter 1 we encountered the toponym Bydogoshchi, which recalls the existing village of Vidogoshchi situated by the Volga river. So “b” is indeed almost a “v.”

Останин (35) замечает, что в главе 1 мы сталкиваемся с топомином Быдогощи, напоминающим реальную деревню Видогощи, расположенную на реке Волге. То есть, “б”, действительно, как “в”.

explanatory intratextuality
жэ — та загадочна

We should also consider the fact that this letter lacks a univocal corresponding grapheme in the Latin or Greek alphabets, and it is not known how this character was derived. Moreover, the use of the term “zagadochna” may recall the famous concept of the supposed “mysterious Russian soul” (zagadochnaya russkaya dusha). Following this, we could consider the letter “zhe” here as an objectivation of “Russianness” and, therefore, of the supposed “Russian mysteriousness”.

Следует заметить, что у этой буквы отсутствует унифокальный греческий или латинский аналог, и происхождение это буквенного символа неизвестно. Более того, использование прилагательного “загадочная” напоминает известную концепцию “загадочной русской души”. Исходя из этого, мы можем сделать вывод о том, что буква “ж” здесь представляет собой воплощение “русскости” и, соответственно, “русской загадочности”.

symbol language Russia
В эту пору, траченный бытовыми невзгодами и хлесткими обложными ливнями

Similar phrasing is used in chapter five: “а теперь отощавшаго, траченнаго курительными и бытовыми порывами” (“nut now thinned, reduced by smoking and bodily urges”) (R189/E69–70).

Похожая формулировка встречается в пятой главе: “а теперь отощавшаго, траченнаго курительными и бытовыми порывами” (R189/E69–70).

intratextuality
траченный бытовыми невзгодами и хлесткими обложными ливнями

Presumably, it is the end of summer - beginning of fall.

time
кубарэ

Unusual (and mockingly foreign) word. It may derive from the word “kubar’”, informally used by students of the naval academy to define a ship cabin.

Необычное (и мнимо-иностранное) слово, наверное от разговорного морского термина “кубарь,” каюта.

foreign neologism location setting
я

“Ya […] prorok”: a recurrent image in Sokolov’s work. See also his essay “The Anxious Pupa.”

Я […] пророк: повторяющийся образ. См. также “Тревожная куколка”.

intertextuality self-reference
пророк, два часа светлых спроворивший в июле месяце у христиан

Ilya frequently compares himself to the prophet Elijah, whose name day—July 20 Old Style / August 2 New Style—marks the transition from summer to fall. Ostanin indicates that this is also a reference to the following proverb: “Петр и Павел час убавил, а Илья Пророк два уволок” (Peter and Paul stole an hour, and Ilya the Prophet took away two) (35). The exact quantities are not actually correct, but the meaning is that on these saints respective days (July 12 and August 2) the sun moves faster than on the longest days of summer.

Илья часто сравнивает себя с пророком Илией, чьи именины — 20 июля по старому стилю/ 2 августа по новому стилю — определяет переход лета в осень. Останин замечает, что это также отсылка к следующей пословице: “Петр и Павел час убавил, а Илья Пророк два уволок” (35). Суть в том, что в дни этих святых (12 июля и 2 августа) световой день на один и, соответственно, два часа короче, чем в день летнего солнцестояния, хотя на самом деле численные значения не совсем соответствуют действительности.

explanatory time intertextuality
спроворивший

Colloquial: to filch, steal.

register/style
завершение

It is presumably the end of summer, since Ilya intends to celebrate the “end” of his seasonal work.

time explanatory
напрочь

Colloquial: entirely.

Разговорное: совсем, вовсе.

register/style
вдрызг

Colloquial: to smithereens, totally, completely.

Разговорное: окончательно, вдребезги, полностью.

register/style
промысла

Seasonal work.

Сезонная работа.

explanatory
Встретился в слепой местности некоторый слепец, и он вызвался проводить на роздых к воде. И поплелся за ним, ему доверяя во всем, но темнота нас объяла, и он не заметил поэтому ямы ловчей и ухнулся. Сверзился вслед за вожатым и я, так как мой подпоясок связан был с подпояском его крепкой вервой, чтобы не растеряться нам.

A reference to Matthew 15:14 (“If the blind lead the blind, both will fall into a pit”) and Bruegel the Elder’s 1568 painting The Blind Leading the Blind. This segment is Ilya’s direct speech to the people gathered in the “kubare,” to whom he recounts what has happened to him. However, given the fact that Ilya is also by his name and character linked to the prophet Elijah, his story turns into an allegoric parable in order to help Petr understand the origin of the letter zh (and presumably, to find the drozhzhy, yeast, he is searching for).

Отсылка к Матфея 15:14 (“Если слепой ведет слепого, то оба упадут в яму”) и картине Брейгеля Старшего Притча о слепых, написанной в 1568 году. Изображено ниже:

В этом отрывке прямая речь Ильи — обращение к собранным в кубаре людям, которым он рассказывает, что с ним произошло. Однако, учитывая то, что имя и персонаж Ильи связаны с пророком Илией, рассказ превращается в аллегорическую притчу, чтобы объяснить Петру проихождение буквы “ж” (и, предположительно, найти дрожжи, которые он ищет).

intertextuality bible religion character foreign
в слепой местности

A “blind place,” meaning an unsightly or unknown place. Compare to “В местности глухой” in chapter 1 (R157/E15).

“Слепая местность” означает неизвестное, неизведанное место. Можно сравнить с “В местности глухой” в главе 1 (R157/E15).

intratextuality explanatory language
в слепой местности некоторый слепец

Figura etymologica (slepoj - slepec).

Этимологическая фигура речи (слепой-слепец).

sound stylistic device
слепец

One more character with disability in this novel.

structure character
роздых

Colloquial: breather, brief rest, repose.

Разговорное: кратковременный отдых, передышка.

register/style
поплелся

Colloquial: to drag oneself along, push off.

Разговорное: с трудом пойти следом, потянуться.

register/style
ухнулся

Colloquial: to fall with great noise.

Разговорное: упасть с громким шумом.

register/style
Сверзился

Colloquial: to collapse, tumble down.

Разговорное: тяжело упасть.

register/style
вожатым

Archaism: leader.

Архаизм: ведущий, лидер.

archaism register/style
подпоясок

Colloquial: belt, something that binds.

Разговорное: пояс, то, чем подпоясываются.

register/style
подпояском

Colloquial: belt, something that binds.

Разговорное: пояс, то, чем подпоясываются.

register/style
вервой

Верёвка (rope).

Веревка.

language
башками

Colloquial word: head. Archaism: head of a large fish, head meat. Used several times throughout the novel (R152, 174, 189, 264, 280). Animal motif.

Разговорное: голова. Архаизм: голова крупой рыбы, головизна (мясо головы). Несколько раз встречается в романе (R152, 174, 189, 264, 280). Мотив животных.

intratextuality register/style archaism motif
вот и не растерялись

Repetition.

Повтор.

rhythm
дурили

Colloquial: to goof around, act like a fool.

Разговорное: делать глупости, вести себя, как дураки.

register/style
в добрый час

Set expression: good fortune (as a greeting, similar to “good morning”). However, here, given the “ne” that precedes it, this expression has a literal meaning of an “inappropriate time,” suggesting that it was a bad idea to continue the journey during the dark time of the day.

Устойчивое выражение: “добрый час” (как приветствие, “доброе утро”). Однако, здесь буквально означает “неподходящее время”, намекая на то, что продолжать путь в темное время суток было плохим решением.

phraseologism time
товарищи по беде

It may conceal an allusion to the expression “друзья познаются в беде” (friends in need), from the Latin “amicus certus in re incerta.”

Возможно, ссылается на устойчивое выражение “друзья познаются в беде” (с латинского “amicus certus in re incerta”)

phraseologism
завод мой точильный

Ilya’s grinding stand.

Точильный станок Ильи.

explanatory
пуще

Colloquial: more than, worse than.

Разговорное: сильнее, хуже.

register/style
Лопнуло генеральное колесо

A first explanation of the origin/birth of the letter zhe (that is, the result of the breaking up of Ilya’s grinding stand).

Первое объяснение рождения буквы ж (то есть, сломанный “точильный завод” Ильи).

intratextuality explanatory
бондаря

Ukranian: cooper. Another form, бочарник, appears in chapter 3 (R164/E28).

Украинское: бочар, мастер по изготовлению бочек. Другая форма, бочарник, встречается в главе 3 (R164/E28).

foreign intratextuality
ущербной

Ilya refers to his damaged sharpening wheel, but ущербный may also refer to the waning moon, a key image in the novel, as seen in the opening line.

Илья имеет в виду поврежденное точильное колесо, но прилагательное “ущербный” может также описывать месяц (луну), ключевой образ в романе, как становится ясно с первой строки.

intratextuality symbol
зимние я фатеры

Ostanin identifies this as an allusion to Mikhail Lermontov’s 1837 poem “Borodino”: “Что ж мы? на зимние квартиры?” (35). Read the poem and an English translation here. Responding to a question regarding similarities between his style and that of Vladimir Nabokov, Sokolov said, “I’ve surmized that a similarity in our styles might come from a common source: We share favorite writers. It may be enough to point to Gogol’ and Lermontov. By connecting these two, a system of coordinates appears, from which one can determine style. Of course, only if both writers are favorites” (Podshivalov, “A Conversation” 353). For more on Sokolov and Nabokov, see D. Barton Johnson’s “Saša Sokolov and Vladimir Nabokov.” There, the critic writes, “After arriving in Vienna in October 1975, Sokolov read (in Russian) Lolita and The Gift and was surprised to note similarities between the avant-garde prose style of Škola dlja durakov and Nabokov’s prose techniques […] Dismayed, Sokolov determined to develop a new, distinctive voice, one not under the shadow of the older writer. This search led to the exotic language of his 1980 Meždu sobakoj i volkom” (154). Evgeny Sokolov calls Between Dog and Wolf a “poema squared,” riffing on Gogol’s characterization of his novel Dead Souls as a poema (10).

Останин определяет это как ссылку на на стихотворение М. Лермонтова “Бородино”: “Что ж мы? на зимние квартиры?” (35). Прочитать оригинал и английский перевод стихотворения можно здесь. Отвечая на вопрос о схожести его стиля с набоковским, Соколов сказал: “Я предполагаю, что схожесть наших стилей объясняется общим источником: мы делим любимых писателей. Достаточно хотя бы отметить Гоголя и Лермонтова. Их соединение приводит к образованию системы координат, из которой можно определить стиль. Конечно же, такое возможно только если оба писателя любимые” (Podshivalov, “A Conversation” 353). Больше о Соколове и Набокове можно прочитать у Д. Бартона Джонсона “Саша Соколов и Владимир Набоков”.
