Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif intertextuality
припасены

Colloquial: to have in reserve.

Разговорное: иметь в запасе.

register/style
Покрова

October 14 (1, old calendar). In this day, according to folk tradition, fall and winter meet.

14 октября (1 по старому стилю). В этот день, согласно народному поверью, встречаются осень и зима.

time explanatory Russia folklore
щеголяю

Colloquial: to flaunt, sport

Разговорное: рисоваться, красоваться.

register/style
обвык

Colloquial: to get used to.

Разговорное: привыкнуть.

register/style
бумага наждачная

Sandpaper.

Шлифовальная бумага. Изображено ниже:

explanatory
пята

Archaism: heel, foot.

Архаизм: пятка, задняя часть стопы.

archaism register/style
сетую

High: to lament.

Высокое: жаловаться.

register/style
кое-кто познаменитее нас претерпел, рекомендуя и нам

According to Ostanin, a reference to the proverb “Христос [Бог] терпел и нам велел” (Christ [God] suffered and made it our lot” (38).

Согласно Останину, отсылка к поговорке: “Христос [Бог] терпел и нам велел” (38).

intertextuality religion folklore
Покров

October 14 (1, old calendar). In this day, according to folk tradition, fall and winter meet.

14 октября (1 по старому стилю). В этот день, согласно народному поверью, встречаются осень и зима.

time Russia explanatory folklore
грязи наши сплотит мороз

Another merging of opposites: dark and light.

Очередное соединение противоположностей: темное и светлое.

theme
валенок

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

Russia motif intertextuality
анчутка

Bad spirit, demon.

Злой дух, бес.

language
сковало

When the river freezes.

Когда замерзла река.

explanatory
вервием

Dated: rope.

Устаревшее: то же, что веревка.

register/style
снегурок

A type of ice skates, usually for beginners. In this picture: Ivan Tolstoy’s (son of Lev Tolstoy) snegurki. Коньки, обычно для начинающих. В картине: снегурки Вани Тольстого.

explanatory
шуруй

Colloquial: to go.

Разговорное: иди.

register/style
сапог

Boots with high tops. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif intertextuality
сапога

Boots with high tops. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. motif intertextuality
валенком

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

Традиционные русские валяные сапоги. Изображено ниже:

Мотив обуви.

Russia motif intertextuality
подтибрил

Colloquial: to steal.

Разговорное: украсть.

register/style
некогда

Literary: once, at some point.

Литературное: однажды.

register/style
Холод, голод

Paronomasia.

Парономазия.

sound stylistic device
тиф — все, что хочешь, а с валенками — дефектив

Rhyme (tif - defektiv).

Рифма (тиф - дефектив).

rhyme
валенками

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

Традиционные русские валяные сапоги. Изображено ниже:

Russia motif intertextuality
дефектив

Instead of defitsit (deficit, shortage), Ilya creates a noun, defektiv (defect), from the adjective defektivny (defective).

Илья путает слова, имея в виду “дефицит”.

register/style neologism
попеременке

Colloquial: alternately.

Разговорное: по очереди.

register/style
променады

French: walk, stroll.

Французское: прогулка.

foreign
соображал на двоих

A variation of the set expression “soobrazhat’ na troikh”: to drink in company, sharing the costs of alcohol. The expression dates back to the Soviet times. Once again, the book touches upon the theme of drinking.

Разновидность устойчивого выражения “сообразить на троих”: пить в компании, деля стоимость алкоголя поровну. Выражение берет начало из советстких времен. В очередной раз роман касается темы пьянства.

phraseologism theme
подфартило

Colloquial: to be lucky.

Разговорное: посчастливиться.

register/style
у него этой нет, а у меня противоположной

Ilya and his friend are both missing one leg each.

У Ильи и его друга не хватает по ноге.

explanatory
снюхались

Colloquial: literally to recognize one another by the sniff (as dogs), that is to say, to start a good relationship. Once again Ilya is associated with animals’ behaviour. Animal-human motif.

Разговорное: буквально узнать друг друга по нюху (как собаки), то есть, положить начало хорошим взаимоотношениям. Снова Илья ассоциируется с животным поведением.

register/style character motif
бобики

Common name for dogs.

Распространенное имя для собак.

explanatory
Два сапога — пара

The phraseologism (as elsewhere in the book) turns real as they both have only one leg. Furthermore, D.B. Johnson, writes: “The proverbial idea ‘two boots make a pair’ supports the suggestion that the two men are related, although the point is made more forcefully (and grotesquely) by their sharing (and stealing) a single set of footwear. It also hints at the intergrading of personalities so typical of the murky world between dog and wolf. The other function is more speculative. Both father and son are lame. They do not know each other. The son is destined to kill the father. It appears that they have both loved the same woman, i.e. the mentally defective girl who shares much of her past (including the slipper episode) with Orina, the wife and mother. The parallel to the Oedipus legend is striking: father and son are lame (cf. the etymologies of Laios and Oedipus), they do not recognize each other, the son kills the father, and loves (a version of) his mother” (“The Galoshes Manifesto”165). Shoe motif.

Фразеологизм (как и в других местах в романе) воплощается в жизнь, ведь у них обоих есть только по одной ноге.

phraseologism structure character motif language
сапога

Boots with high tops. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif intertextuality
перевязку

Therapeutic procedure, which includes treatment of the wound with an antiseptic agent.

Терапевтическая процедура, подразумевающая обрабатывание раны антисептическим средством.

explanatory
сестры

Implied: “medsestry,” nurse.

Подразумевается: у медсестры.

language
отовариться

Colloquial: to obtain, to gain, to acquire something.

Разговорное: получить что-либо.

register/style
из дамского

Implied “otdelenie”: from the women sector at the hospital.

Подразумевается: из дамского отделения, то есть, женского отделения больницы.

language
Куда, поется, правое копыто, туда и левая клешня

A variation of the saying “Kuda kon’ s kopytom, tuda i rak s kleshnyoi”: of someone who acts as if they were better or stronger than they actually are in order to imitate somebody. An echo of the two banks of the Volga resembling each other.

Разновидность высказывания “Куда конь с копытом, туда и рак с клешней”: о человеке, подражающем кому-либо, чтобы казаться сильнее или лучше. Отголосок двух берегов Волги, похожих друг на друга.

phraseologism
променада

French: walk, stroll.

Французское: прогулка.

foreign
студеном

Colloquial: bitterly cold, freezing.

Разговорное: очень холодный.

register/style
доходяга

Colloquial: extremely feeble, close to death.

Разговорное: крайне ослабленный, близкий к смерти.

register/style
доходяга ходячий

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

stylistic device sound
липы сиротские

Ostanin (38) suggests that these trees are situated in the park of a former orphanage (sirotsky priyut). Plant motif.

language motif
отчий

Archaic/poetic: father’s (instead of the more common “otsovsky”). Ostanin (38) intends “otchy sad” as a synonym for kindergarten. Ilya’s potential son, Yakov, will be introduced soon after.

Архаизм/поэтическое: отцовский. Останин (38) предполагает, что отчий сад синонимичен детскому саду. Яков, потенциальный сын Ильи, будет представлен позднее.

register/style archaism intratextuality
валенки

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

Традиционные русские валяные сапоги. Изображено ниже:

Мотив обуви.

Russia motif intertextuality
донимает

Colloquial: to annoy, to torment.

Разговорное: раздражать, мучить.

register/style
в глаза мои суровые, взгляни, быть может, в последний раз

Quotation from one of the most famous prison camp songs, written in the late 1940s “Etap na sever” (Step towards the North). Read the original here. Watch performance here.

Цитата из одной из самых известных тюремных песен “Этап на Север”, написанной в поздние 1940-е. Прочитать слова можно здесь.

intertextuality music
напялим

Colloquial, low: to put on.

Разговорное, просторечное: надеть.

register/style
поскакали

This verb is usually linked with horses: it is but one more example of Ilya being described having animals’ habits. Animal-human motif.

Этот глагол обычно относится к лошадям: очередной пример описания привычек Ильи, свойственных животным.

character motif
Распрекрасно снаружи — родина. Вроде — мать, но хитра поразительно, охмуряет. Поначалу все кажется — земля как земля, только бедная, нету в ней ничего. Но обживешься, присмотришься — все в ней есть, кроме валенок.

Russia, a “cunning” and “deceptive” “motherland”, is described as rich in its essence, although poor at first sight. Ilya uses similar wording at the beginning of chapter 6 (R189/E71). Mark Lipovetsky comments that “Russia is a figurative synonym for Orina, both as the mother who abandons her child (in relation to Yakov) and as an unfaithful lover (in relation to Ilya). Moreover, the author, like Ilya, longs for his beloved, tries to meet her and runs away from her, hates her and pities her” (Russian Postmodernist Fiction 143).

Россия, “хитрая” и “охмуряющая” родина, описана как богатая в своей сущности, но с бедная с первого взгляда. Илья использует похожую формулировку в главе 6 (R189/E71).

intratextuality Russia
валенок

Traditional Russian winter felt boots. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

Традиционные русские валяные сапоги. Изображены ниже:

Мотив обуви.

Russia motif intertextuality
Ковыляем

Colloquial: to hobble, to dodder, to toddle, to stump.

Разговорное: идти прихрамывая, спотыкаясь.

register/style
педиатрическим кущам

“Pediatric haunts” would align with Ostanin’s reading of “отчий сад” as a reference to детский сад (kindergarten) (38).

“Педиатрические кущи” соответствуют предложенной Останиным интерпретации фразы “отчий сад” как детский сад (38).

intratextuality
кущам

Archaic: hut, dwelling place.

Архаизм: хижина, жилище.

archaism
горка вам ледяная

Traditional winter pastime.

Традиционный зимний досуг. Изображено ниже:

explanatory Russia
крепость снежная

Traditional Russian winter pastime.

Традиционный русский зимний досуг. Изображено ниже:

explanatory Russia
в Ботфортове

As Ostanin suggests (38), in Botfortovo Ilya mixes up the term “botforty” (Peter the Great’s favorite boots), the last name of one of the Emperor’s close associates, François Le Fort (or Lefort; 1656-1699), and the Lefortovo district in Moscow, founded in 1699 and named after him. The narrator in chapter 9 does the same (R215/E115). D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

Как предполагает Останин, в слове “Ботфортово” Илья путает “ботфорты” (любимые сапоги Петра Великого) с именем одного из приближенных императора, Франца Яковлевича Лефорта (1656-1699), и районом Лефортово в Москве, основанного в 1699 году и названного в его честь. Рассказчик делает то же самое в главе 9 (R215/E115). Мотив обуви.

language motif intratextuality Russia intertextuality
Петра Алексеича

Peter the Great (1672-1725).

Петр Великий (1672-1725).

Russia
харчах

Low: food.

Просторечное: еда.

register/style
щеки, что называется, со спины видать

Set expression: a fat person.

Устойчивое выражения для описания тучного человека.

phraseologism
Накатаемся

Colloquial: to have one’s fill of riding.

Разговорное: покататься вдоволь.

register/style
исчумажемся

Sokolov’s neologism from “chumazy” (colloquial: dirty, also used offensively to define black people), meaning: to smear one’s hands, face, body with something dark, e.g. clay, soot.

Неологизъм Соколова от “чумазый” (разговорное: грязный; употребляется и пренебрежительно относительно людям черного кожа), значит: вымазать руки, лицо, тело чем-либо темным, например, глиной, сажей.

neologism register/style
пацанвой

Colloquial: kids.

Разговорное: дети.

register/style
Ему и больно, и смешно, а врач грозит ему в окно

Quote from Pushkin’s Onegin (chapter 5.II): in the original, it is “mama” who menaces at the window. Read the original here.

Цитата из “Евгения Онегина” Пушкина (глава 5, строфа II): в оригинале, в окно грозит мать. Прочитать оригинал можно здесь.

intertextuality
особливо

Dated/colloquial: especially, particularly.

Устаревшее/разговорное: особенно, в частности.

register/style
покуда

Low: while, at the same time.

Просторечное: пока, в то время как.

register/style
пялиться

Dated: to get closer to something. Here, to stare.

Устаревшее: приближаться. В данном контексте, пристально смотреть.

register/style
рожа

Colloquial: face.

Разговорное: лицо.

register/style
пижамина реет пуста

Since Ilya is missing a leg.

explanatory
Люша

Diminutive form of Ilya.

Уменьшительная форма имени “Илья”.

character
Люша

Diminutive form of Ilya.

Уменьшительная форма имени “Илья”.

character
историю-то сочини, а на закорках-то провези, а культю-то свою не таи

Rhythm (thanks to parallel syntax and imperatives).

Ритм (через синтаксический параллелизм и повелительные глаголы).

rhythm
 на закорках

Colloquial: to carry on one’s back.

Разговорное: понести на спине.

register/style
таи, показывай

Rhyme.

Рифма.

sound rhyme
плешь проели

Set expression: to tire someone with requests.

Устойчивое выражение: утомить просьбами.

phraseologism
Алфеев

Iakov Alfeev (James, son of Alphaeus) was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is also known as James the Less, or “the minor,” “the little,” “the lesser,” “the younger.” In the next chapter, Yakov will acquire a different last name, Palamakhterov: his changing last names may also be “justified” by the implied semantic link existing between his first name and the word “yakoby,” literally maybe, perhaps.

Иаков Алфеев был одним из 12 апостолов. Он также известен как Иаков Младший, или Меньший. В следующей главе, Якову будет присвоено другая фамилия, Паламахтеров: его изменяющиеся фамилии можно “объяснить” семантической связью между его именем и словом “якобы”, то есть, будто.

character bible language intertextuality religion
липли

Colloquial: to hassle.

Разговорное: приставать, докучать.

register/style
банными листиками

Set expression (banny list): an annoying person.

Устойчивое выражение (банный лист): назойливый, надоедливый человек.

phraseologism
Яков

Although appearing only now, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the only fictional author of the entire book. In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is “not fresh and not young”); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov plays a central role also in the structuring of the plot, as it is him who kills Ilya in revenge.

Несмотря на позднее появление в романе, этот полиморфный герой играет центральную роль в романе, являюсь одновременно собачником, охотником, поэтом, художником и, возможно, единственным вымышленным автором целой книги. В ответе Смиту, опубликованному в статье 1987 года, Соколов отмечает: “Стихотворные главы написаны Яковом. Он никак ко мне не относится, но он должен быть и является человеком высокой культуры, ведь он и есть тот самый художник, описанный в прозаических главах (не написанных Ильей) “Ловчая повесть”, где он живет в доме с матерью, юноша, влюбленный в простодушную девушку, которую уводят матросы; автор эскизов и “Автопортрета в мундире”, и так далее; (И. конечно, в этой главе он также охотник и поэт, который “несвеж и немолод”); “Ловчая повесть, или Картинки с выставки”, где он — Яков Ильич Паламахтеров, “неподкупный свидетель и доезжачiй своего практическаго и безжалостнаго времени”, который представляет сцену из этнографии XIX века с участием своего прадеда; “Картинки с выставки” (9), в которой он наблюдает за сценами уличной жизни сквозь окно кадетского училища; см. также похожие места в романе, 13 и 16. Все они написаны с позиции автора, но стилизированного автора, то есть, не от меня непосредственно. Яков — поэт, художник, мечтатель, представитель интеллигенции, который родился и вырос в городе. Он поселяется у Итиля уже в зрелом возрасте” (327). Яков играет центральную роль в структуре сюжета, ведь это он убивает Илью в порыве мести.

character structure
Ильичу

Yakov Alfeev’s patronymic suggests Ilya is his father. Yet, the suggestion is debatable. D.B. Johnson noted: “Yakov is Ilya’s son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (…). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) ‘marries’ a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (1984; 211-212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter’s dogs for a wolf and kills it. For a consideration of Sokolov’s mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova’s “Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov.”

Отчество Якова Алфеева указывает на то, что Илья — его отец. Однако, это предположение оспоримо. Д. Б. Джонсон замечает: “Яков — сын Ильи, в той степени, в которой что-то может быть чем-либо в сумереченом мире между собакой и волком. И Яков, и Илья остаются в неведении этого факта, однако позже, когда их жизненные пути как собачника и точильщика фатально пересекаются, они также неосведомлены о их временной дружбе в больнице. (…). [Яков] повторяет роль Эдипа. Он неосознанно убивает своего отца и (пусть и не буквально) “женится” на версии своей матери. Соколов воплотил греческий миф о Эдипе среди вод Волги” (1984; 211-212). На самом деле, Илья будет убит Яковом в отместку за то, что первый (в сумерки, переходя замерзшую реку) принял одну из собак последнего за волка и убил ее. Анализ мифопоэтики Соколова приведен в “Творчестве Саши Соколова в контексте литературного процеса 60-80-х годов” И. Ащеуловой (Ashcheulova).

character
Он же поэт, стихотворец

Yakov is presumably also the author of the Notes.

Яков, преположительно, является автором записок.

character intratextuality
стишата

Colloquial (instead of “stikhi”): verses, poems.

Разговорное: стихи.

register/style
отменные

Dated: excellent.

Устаревшее: отличный.

register/style
Сидор

The investigator for special cases Pozhilykh to whom Ilya is addressing his letter.

Следователь по особым делам Пожилых, кому Илья пишет свое письмо.

character intratextuality
Исидóр

Ostanin notes that this is a reference to Isidore of Chios, a martyr killed by order of Decius (39). His feast day is May 14.

Останин отмечает отсылку в Исидору Хиосскому, убитому по приказу Декия мученику (39). День его поминовения — 14 мая.

religion
они с картинками

We can understand this hint literally (these poems come accompanied by pictures, drawings) or metaphorically (they are structured on depicted pictures, in an ekphrastic manner). Moreover, this is resonant with some chapters’ title, “Kartinki s vystavki,” Pictures from an Exhibition.

Это можно интерпретировать буквально (стихи сопровождаются рисунками) или метафорически (они основаны на образах, в экфрастической манере). Более того, это резонирует с некоторыми названиями глав, например, “Картинки с выставки”.

explanatory intratextuality structure
поэма про пса бездомного

A reference to Note XXXII, “Eclogue”: “Dog decided to stick there with me. / ’Twas considered homeless, however, / Rather fat it appeared to be.” (R270/E210).

Отсылка к Записке XXXII, “Эклога”: “Собака / За мной увязалась одна. / Бездомной считалась, однако / Казалась довольно жирна” (R270/E210).

intratextuality
де

Colloquial: says.

Разговорное: говорит.

register/style
дрючкой

Slang: sex, young girl, prostitute. Here, referring to her genitals.

Жаргонное: молодая любовница, проститутка. Здесь, относится к ее половым органам.

register/style
забор, больно этой штучке, сделался запор

Rhyme through paronomasia (zabor - zapor).

Рифма через парономазию (забор - запор).

stylistic device rhyme sound
Фомич

The investigator for special cases Pozhilykh to whom Ilya is addressing his letter.

Следователь по особым делам Пожилых, кому Илья пишет свое письмо.

character intratextuality
кобелей, сделали что надо — стало веселей

Rhyme (kobelei - veselei).

Рифма: кобелей - веселей.

sound rhyme
спиногрызам

Colloquial: kids.

Разговорное: дети.

register/style
детворой

Colloquial: kids (a group of), children.

Разговорное: дети, группа дети.

register/style
вечереет

So it’s again twilight time.

И снова время сумерек.

time theme
театр

As will be explained just further below, the “anatomichesky teatr” is here implied.

explanatory setting
особился

Dated: to keep to oneself.

Устаревшее: держаться особняком, отдельно от других.

register/style
под номером раз

Address: house no. 1.

Адрес: дом под номером 1.

setting
горбатый

Humpback. The image of humpbacked people and animals appears several times throughout the novel (R152, 168, 180, 184, 187, 189, 200, 217, 103, 268/E6, 61, 66, 69, 89, 208).

Страдающий кифозом. Образ горбатых людей и животных неоднократно встречается в романе: (R152, 168, 180, 184, 187, 189, 200, 217, 103, 268/E6, 61, 66, 69, 89, 208). Мотив животных.

intratextuality
часовня из бывших с ампутированным крестом

This detail possibly witnesses of the Soviet epoch as time setting of the book. Since the setting is that of an hospital and a morgue, Ilya logically chooses the verb “to amputate.”

Эта деталь указывает на советскую эпоху как время действия романа. Так как действие происходит в больнице и морге, Илья использует логически подходящий глагол “ампутировать”.

setting Russia time
крестом

The cross is a crucial symbol in A School for Fools, more precisely in the story/parable titled “The Carpenter in the Desert” contained in it. As the story tells, the carpenter wonders: ‘Fine, I don’t have material to build a house, a carousel, or a crate, but I have two boards and one good nail’ (R115/E141). He then makes a cross out of these poor materials. Later on, some people come and ask him to help them crucify a man; at first, he refuses the idea, but then they persuade him successfully. As the crucified man is dying he decides to tell the carpenter his story, which echoes the carpenter’s. ‘You fool,’ he addresses the carpenter, ‘haven’t you understood yet there’s absolutely no difference between us, that you and I are one and the same man’ (R117–118/E143). In the end, the narrator says, ‘the carpenter died’ (R118/E144).

intratextuality intertextuality self-reference
растенья

Here as elsewhere in the text, there is a frequent use of dated suffixes.

register/style
белеющие

Meaning “to turn” white but also “to dawn.”

анатомы

Being white, willows resemble doctors (here: pathologists) dressed in white coats.

Благодаря своей белой окраске, ивы напоминают докторов (здесь: патологоанатомов), одетых в белые халаты.

explanatory
анатомы. А табличка старинного начертания вам сообщала: анатомический театр.

Figura etymologica (anatomy-anatomicheskyj).

Повтор с вариацией (анатомы-анатомический).

stylistic device
старинного начертания

This sign is presumably written according to the pre-reform alphabet (before 1918).

Надпись на табличке сделана, предположительно, с использованием дореформенной орфографии (до 1918).

explanatory
артистов

That is: dead people.

То есть: трупы.

explanatory
Санитар

A recurrent image also in A School for fools and in Sokolov’s own biography (he himself worked as a orderly).

Повторяющийся образ. Встречается также в “Школе для дураков” и биографии Соколова.

intertextuality self-reference
нараспах

Colloquial: same as “нараспашку” (open wide).

Разговорное: то же, что нараспашку (широко раскрыть).

register/style
за показы пока
sound play
за показы пока не взимаю

Alliteration (z, p).

Аллитерация (з, п).

sound stylistic device
как облупленных

Set expression (“kak obluplennogo”): in detail.

Устойчивое выражение: очень хорошо, до мельчайших подробностей.

phraseologism
назубок

Colloquial: very good.

Разговорное: очень хорошо.

register/style
кто отравился

The character Kaluga eats belladonna berries and dies from poisoning (R225/E132).

Калуга, один из персонажей, съедает волчьи ягоды и умирает от отравления (R225/E132).

intratextuality character
кто отравился, кто раком сгорел, кого придавило, кто просто по глупости

Death, like in previous and successive chapters (e.g. the ice skaters’ fate in ch. 1), continues to play a big role.

Смерть, как в предыдущих и последующих главах (например, рок конькобежцев в главе 1), продолжает играть значительную роль.

theme
Лет несолидных

That is to say: young.

То есть: молодая.

language
деваха

Colloquial: girl.

Разговорное: девочка, девушка.

register/style
Тощеватая

Colloquial: very skinny.

Разговорное: очень худая.

register/style
кучерявый

Colloquial: curly.

Разговорное: волнистый.

register/style
кончина ей — не кручина

Alliteration (k, n, ch).

Аллитерация (к, н, ч).

sound stylistic device
кручина

Dated: deep sadness.

Устаревшее: глубокая печаль.

register/style
как ни при чем и не тронулась телом ничуть, не в пример многочисленным. Смею надеяться, что серафимы хранили ее сильней

There is something saintly about her in this suggestion of incorruptibility.

В ней есть что-то святое, на что указывает ее нетленность.

religion
серафимы

The highest ranked Christian angel class, the seraphim are best known from Isaiah 6:1–8: “In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord, high and exalted, seated on a throne; and the train of his robe filled the temple. Above him were seraphim, each with six wings: With two wings they covered their faces, with two they covered their feet, and with two they were flying. And they were calling to one another: ‘Holy, holy, holy is the Lord Almighty; the whole earth is full of his glory.’” They are also mentioned in Alexander Pushkin’s seminal 1826 poem “The Prophet”: “Tormented by a spiritual thirst, / I stumbled through a gloomy waste, / And there a six-winged seraph / Appeared before me at the crossroad.” Read the original and this English translation here. Later mentioned in chapter 6 (R195/E80).

Серафимы — высший ангельский чин, описаны в книге Исаии 6:1-8: “В год смерти царя Озии видел я Господа, сидящего на престоле высоком и превознесенном, и края риз Его наполняли весь храм. Вокруг Него стояли Серафимы; у каждого из них по шести крыл: двумя закрывал каждый лице свое, и двумя закрывал ноги свои, и двумя летал. И взывали они друг ко другу и говорили: Свят, Свят, Свят Господь Саваоф! вся земля полна славы Его!”. Также упоминаются в судьбоносном стихотворении А. Пушкина 1826 года “Пророк”: “Духовной жаждою томим, / В пустыне мрачной я влачился, - / И шестикрылый серафим / На перепутьи мне явился”. Прочитать стихотворение в оригинале и английском переводе можно здесь. Позже упоминаются в главе 6 (R195/E80).

religion intertextuality bible intratextuality
Оря

The girl’s fate reminds Ilya of Orina.

Судьба девушки напоминает Илье об Орине.

character
Оря

Diminutive form of Orina. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
приголубила

Colloquial: to be kind to someone.

Разговорное: приласкать.

register/style
Илью

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality folklore character
на худой конец

Set expression: at the worst.

Устойчивое выражение: в худшем случае.

phraseologism
красотулю

Endearment, colloquial: beauty, beautiful lady.

Ласкательное, разговорное: красавица.

register/style
Несчастие — это если нет счастия, а счастие, Оря, это если несчастия нет.

Ilya is a bit tautologic. This phrase is repeated also in chapter 8 (R205/E97).

Илья здесь повторяет себя. Также встречается в главе 8: “Что есть счастье и что есть несчастие, милый Вы мой? Не пасуйте, ответ незатейлив: счастие — это когда оно есть.” (R205/E97).

character intratextuality
Оря

Diminutive form of Orina. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
казенного чистяку

According to Ostanin, medicinal spirits (39).

Согласно Останину, медицинский спирт (39).

explanatory
толика

Colloquial: quantity, sum.

Разговорное: часть, доля.

register/style
Вечеряем

Colloquial: to have dinner.

Разговорное: ужинать.

register/style
тартáре

The accent should be put on the first vowel, but apparently Ilya is not aware of this (or mixes it up with the toponym “TatAriya/TartAriya”). In Greek mythology, Tartarus is the abyss where wicked people are tormented and suffer, and where souls are judged after death. In the Middle Ages, the most remote corners of the earth started to be called Tartarus. It should be kept in mind that Sokolov himself worked in a morgue for some time in 1961 after completing school.

Ударение должно стоять на первом слоге, но Илья или не знает об этом, или путает с топонимом “Татария / Тартария”. В греческой мифологии, Тартаром называлась бездна, в которой страдали и были мучимы злые люди, и где судились души после смерти. В Средневековье Тартаром стали называть наиболее удалённые уголки земли. Стоит приминать во внимание тот факт, что сам Соколов работал в морге после окончания школы в 1961 году.

explanatory author
не грустно, не гребостно ль? Грубость

Alliteration (gr, stn).

Аллитерация (гр, стн).

sound stylistic device
жестокая, жалости

Alliteration (zh, st).

Аллитерация (ж, ст).

sound stylistic device
потрошат

Colloquial: to open corpses.

Разговорное: вскрывать трупы.

register/style
окочуриться

Low: to die.

Просторечное: умереть.

register/style
разделают под орех

Set expression: to do something in an excellent manner.

Устойчивое выражение: сделать что-либо отличным образом.

phraseologism
меди́чки

Colloquial, feminitive for doctor, medic (medik).

Разговорное, феминитив: врачиня.

register/style
наблатыкались

Low: to learn something, to acquire skills.

Просторечное: научиться, приобрести навыки.

register/style
цапáют

Low: to touch, grab. The stress should fall on the first syllable.

Просторечное: трогать, хватать. Ударение должно падать на первый слог.

register/style
что ни попадя

Set expression: whatever.

Устойчивое выражение: все подряд.

phraseologism
извилиной пошевелите

Metaphoric: to think, make the brain work.

Образно: думать, соображать.

poetic device
дармового горючего

According to Ostanin, medicinal spirits (39).

Согласно Останину, медицинский спирт (39).

explanatory
напропалую

Colloquial: desperately.

Разговорное: отчаянно.

register/style
угораздило

Colloquial: to induce someone to do something.

Разговорное: побудить кого-то что-либо сделать.

register/style
Алфеев

Iakov Alfeev (James, son of Alphaeus) was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is also known as James the Less, or “the minor,” “the little,” “the lesser,” “the younger.” In the next chapter, Yakov will acquire a different last name, Palamakhterov: his changing last names may also be “justified” by the implied semantic link existing between his first name and the word “yakoby,” literally maybe, perhaps.

Иаков Алфеев был одним из 12 апостолов. Он также известен как Иаков Младший, или Меньший. В следующей главе, Якову будет присвоено другая фамилия, Паламахтеров: его изменяющиеся фамилии можно “объяснить” семантической связью между его именем и словом “якобы”, то есть, будто.

intertextuality religion bible character language
Алфеев, Яков Ильич

The word order indicates the bureaucratese.

Порядок слов указывает на бюрократичность.

register/style
Яков

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
Ильич

Yakov Alfeev’s patronymic implies that Ilya is his father. However, this reading is debatable. D.B. Johnson notes: “Yakov is Ilya’s son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (…). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) ‘marries’ a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211–212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter’s dogs for a wolf and attacks it. After the hunters steal his crutches, Yakov returns to murder the dogs. For a consideration of Sokolov’s mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova’s “Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov.”

character intertextuality
военные слухи

Quote from Matthew 24:6.

Цитата из Евангелия от Матфея 24:6.

intertextuality religion bible
затеялась

Colloquial: to show up.

Разговорное: показаться, появиться.

register/style
якобы

An echo of Yakov’s name, of course.

Бесспорно, отголосок имени Якова.

character sound play
как назло

Set expression: as luck would have it.

Устойчивое выражение.

phraseologism
На позиции, вспоминает, девушка провожала бойца

Quote from Mikhail Isakovsky’s poem “Ogonyok” (1942), made popular as a song. Read the original here. Indeed, the song depicts a couple being parted by war, but the thought of her distant love is enough for him to bravely serve against the enemy for the “Soviet motherland.”

Цитата из стихотворения М. Исаковского “Огонек” (1942), ставшего известным как песня. Прочитать оригинал можно здесь.

intertextuality music
шагом марш, разоряется, не то — пристрелю. Ничего не попишешь — пришлось шагать, ну и оторвало, конечно, и выбросило к лешему за фашины

Repetition (sh).

Звуковой повтор (ш).

sound
Ничего не попишешь

Set expression: no way out, no other way, it is what it is.

Устойчивое выражение: нет выбора.

phraseologism
фашины

A bundle of brushwood or other similar material used to strengthen a structure or to create a path. They are frequently used around water. Plant motif. Perhaps also an echo of “фашист” given the WWII theme.

Перевязанный пучок хвороста или подобного материала, использующийся для укрепления структур и прокладывания пути. Мотив растений. Изображено ниже:

Возможно, отголосок слова “фашист”, учитывая тему Второй мировой войны.

explanatory sound play motif
как резаный

Set expression: really loud.

Устойчивое выражение: очень громко.

phraseologism
былинник был

Repetition (byl-).

Повтор.

sound
былинник был речистый

Oblique allusion to the military march song “Marsh Budyonnogo” (1920). Read the original here. Listen to it here.

Косвенная отсылка к маршевой военной песне “Марш Буденного” (1920). Прочитать оригинал слов можно здесь. Послушать запись можно здесь.

intertextuality music
речистый

Colloquial: one who speaks very fluently, elegantly and convincingly.

Разговорное: тот, кто говорит элегантно, убедительно, красноречиво.

register/style
Яков

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
Ильич

Yakov Alfeev’s patronymic implies that Ilya is his father. However, this reading is debatable. D.B. Johnson notes: “Yakov is Ilya’s son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (…). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) ‘marries’ a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211–212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter’s dogs for a wolf and attacks it. After the hunters steal his crutches, Yakov returns to murder the dogs. For a consideration of Sokolov’s mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova’s “Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov.”

character intertextuality
аты-баты, докладывал, шли солдаты, аты-баты, рапортовал, на войну

The insertion of dokladyval and raportoval breaks the rhythm.

Вставка слов “докладывал” и “рапортлвал” нарушает ритм.

rhythm
шли солдаты, аты-баты,

A counting-out rhyme, which serves also as the title of a famous and successful Soviet movie about World War II, released in 1976. In English it is known as “One-Two, Soldiers Were Going…”. The film poster is Read the rhyme here.

Считалка, которая также служит названием известного и успешного советского фильма о Второй мировой войне “Аты-баты, шли солдаты”, выпущенного в 1976. Постер к фильму изображен ниже. Прочитать считалку можно здесь.

intertextuality
в кондукторы пошла и с ревизором в тонкости вошла

An echo of Orina’s promotion at the train station (R155/E12). Railroad theme.

Параллель со служебным продвижением Орины на железнодорожной станции (R155/E12). Тема железной дороги.

intratextuality theme
пошла и с ревизором в тонкости вошла

Rhyme (poshla-voshla).

Рифма (пошла-вошла).

rhyme
с ревизором в тонкости вошла

That is to say: she started an affair.

То есть: начать роман.

explanatory
трупарне

Colloquial: morgue.

Разговорное: морг.

register/style
песочек в часах

Of course, an hourglass.

Речь, конечно, идет о песочных часах.

explanatory time
в первую голову

Set expression: first of all.

Устойчивое выражение: в первую очередь.

phraseologism
амбал

A strong man, from Arabic.

С арабского: сильный человек.

foreign
пожитками

Colloquial: small belongings.

Разговорное: мелкое имущество.

register/style
кандыбают

Colloquial: to hobble, trudge behind.

Разговорное: идти.

register/style
белютня́ми нетрудовитости

Document attesting they are unable to work. The name, however, is an ironic variation; it should be “bulletin’ netrudosposobnosti.”

Документ, подтверждающий нетрудоспособность по состоянию здоровья. Искажено от “бюллетень нетрудоспособности”.

register/style irony
Дело швах

Set expression: bad situation.

Устойчивое выражение: плохая ситуация.

phraseologism
Яковом

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
Ибо

Literary/dated: because, for.

Литуратурное/устаревшее: потому что.

register/style
краснобайства

Dated: gab, grandiloquence, rhetoric, empty talk, lofty speech.

Устаревшее: пустое, бессодержательное красноречие.

register/style
живодера

Literally, a person who tortures animals (at a meat-processing factory or by illegal hunting, usually involving inhumane, torturous methods). Here, metaphorically: bad doctor.

Буквально: тот, кто мучает животных (работний бойни на мясокомбинате или нелегальный охотник, часто использующий жестокие, негуманные методы охоты). Здесь, образно: плохой доктор.

explanatory language
фигýровали

Ilya drops a couple letters from “фигурировать” (to figure).

Илья опускает несколько букв в слове “фигурировать”.

neologism
фигуровали

Ilya drops a couple letters from “фигурировать” (to figure).

Илья опускает несколько букв в слове “фигурировать”.

neologism
Алфеев

Iakov Alfeev (James, son of Alphaeus) was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is also known as James the Less, or “the minor,” “the little,” “the lesser,” “the younger.” In the next chapter, Yakov will acquire a different last name, Palamakhterov: his changing last names may also be “justified” by the implied semantic link existing between his first name and the word “yakoby,” literally maybe, perhaps.

Иаков Алфеев был одним из 12 апостолов. Он также известен как Иаков Младший, или Меньший. В следующей главе, Якову будет присвоено другая фамилия, Паламахтеров: его изменяющиеся фамилии можно “объяснить” семантической связью между его именем и словом “якобы”, то есть, будто.

character bible language intertextuality religion
Илья

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

intertextuality folklore character
Полундра

A synonym for “Beregis’!”, “Take care of yourself.” The term was originally linked with sailing, marines, navy.

Синонимично “Берегись!” Возникло, как предупредительное восклицание в морской пехоте.

language
Яков

Although appearing first only in chapter 4, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the fictional author of the entire book. The ambiguity of his character is rooted in the similarity of his name with the word якобы (allegedly, supposedly). In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article (“The Verse in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”), Sokolov himself stated that: “the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is ‘sophisticated’, because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il’ia) ‘The Hunter’s Tale’, where he is the youth living in his mother’s house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is ‘not fresh and not young’); ‘The Hunter’s Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition’, where he is Iakov Il’ich Palamakhterov, ‘the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,’ and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; ‘Pictures from an Exhibition’ (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov is likewise crucial to the structuring of the plot, as it is he who kills Ilya in revenge for the latter’s attack on his dogs.

character structure
Ильич

Yakov Alfeev’s patronymic implies that Ilya is his father. However, this reading is debatable. D.B. Johnson notes: “Yakov is Ilya’s son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (…). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) ‘marries’ a version of his mother. Sokolov has restaged the Greek myth of Oedipus amid the headwaters of the Volga” (“Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211–212). In fact, Ilya will be killed by Yakov in revenge, as the former (at twilight, while crossing the frozen river) takes one of the latter’s dogs for a wolf and attacks it. After the hunters steal his crutches, Yakov returns to murder the dogs. For a consideration of Sokolov’s mythopoetics, see also Ashcheulova’s “Tvorchestvo Sashi Sokolova v kontekste literaturnogo protsessa 60-80-x godov.”

character intertextuality
налопался

Colloquial: to have enough food (or drink).

Разговорное: наесться вдоволь.

register/style
Алфеев

Iakov Alfeev (James, son of Alphaeus) was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is also known as James the Less, or “the minor,” “the little,” “the lesser,” “the younger.” In the next chapter, Yakov will acquire a different last name, Palamakhterov: his changing last names may also be “justified” by the implied semantic link existing between his first name and the word “yakoby,” literally maybe, perhaps.

Иаков Алфеев был одним из 12 апостолов. Он также известен как Иаков Младший, или Меньший. В следующей главе, Якову будет присвоено другая фамилия, Паламахтеров: его изменяющиеся фамилии можно “объяснить” семантической связью между его именем и словом “якобы”, то есть, будто.

character bible language intertextuality religion
фельдшер

The term is derived from the German Feldscher from the fifteenth century meaning “field shearer.” It was originally used to describe barber surgeons in the German and Swiss armies from the seventeenth until the early 18th century. The term and position was exported by Russian solders serving in Prussia, and the All-Russia Union of Feldshers was established in 1905.

Термин происходит от немецкого слова Feldscher, буквально означающего “полевой цирюльник” в XV веке. Первоначально использовался для описания полевых хирургов в немецкой и швейцарской армиях с XVII века по ранний XVIII век. Сам термин и профессия были привезены русскими солдатами, служившими в Пруссии, и в 1905 году был основан Всероссийский союз фельдшеров. Изображено ниже:

foreign
все как рукой

From the expression “все как рукой сняло” (to recover).

От выражения “все как рукой сняло” (выздороветь).

phraseologism
жилы ты из меня тянешь

Set expression: to torment.

Устойчивое выражение: мучить.

phraseologism
Алфеев

Iakov Alfeev (James, son of Alphaeus) was one of the Twelve Apostles. He is also known as James the Less, or “the minor,” “the little,” “the lesser,” “the younger.” In the next chapter, Yakov will acquire a different last name, Palamakhterov: his changing last names may also be “justified” by the implied semantic link existing between his first name and the word “yakoby,” literally maybe, perhaps.

Иаков Алфеев был одним из 12 апостолов. Он также известен как Иаков Младший, или Меньший. В следующей главе, Якову будет присвоено другая фамилия, Паламахтеров: его изменяющиеся фамилии можно “объяснить” семантической связью между его именем и словом “якобы”, то есть, будто.

character bible language intertextuality religion
кура

Low/dialectical: chicken, hen. Animal motif.

Просторечное/диалектическое: курица. Мотив животных.

register/style motif
Диву я дался

Set expression: to be surprised.

Устойчивое выражение: удивиться.

phraseologism
в который раз

Set expression: again.

Устойчивое выражение: снова.

phraseologism
Откуда, откройте

Alliteration (otk).

Аллитерация (отк).

sound stylistic device
с какого такого шоссе энтузиасты у нас настолько неугомонные есть-пошли

Boguslawski writes: “A combined reference to the famous highway Shosse Entuziastov (Enthusiasts’ Highway) in Moscow and to ‘otkuda est’ poshla russkaia zemlia’ (from whence had the Russian land come), a part of the opening sentence of the twelfth-century Russian chronicle Povest’ vremennykh let (The Tale of Bygone Years)” (“Annotations” 240). Read the original here and an English translation here.

Богуславский пишет: “Комбинированная отсылка к знаменитому Шоссе Энтузиастов в Москве и к ‘откуда есть пошла русская земля’, части первого предложения русской летописи XII века Повести временных лет” (Boguslawski “Annotations” 240). Прочитать оригинал можно здесь, а английский перевод — здесь.

intertextuality Russia
неугомонные

Colloquial: restless.

Разговорное: неутомимый, неспокойный.

register/style
ряба

Reference to “Ryaba the hen”, an Eastern Slavic fairy tale. Read a version of the original here and an English translation here. Animal motif.

Отсылка к “Курочке Рябе”, восточнославянской сказке. Прочитать версию оригинала можно здесь, а английский перевод — здесь. Мотив животных.

intertextuality motif folklore
чумизой

Foxtail millet. Plant motif.

Черный рис, или головчатое просо. Изображено ниже:

motif
де

Colloquial: says.

Разговорное: говорит.

register/style
птахи

Colloquial: small birds. Animal motif.

Разговорное: мелкие птицы. Мотив животных.

register/style motif
турман

A breed of pigeons. Animal motif.

Порода голубей. Изображено ниже:

Мотив животных.

motif
турман Петруху в темя так не клевал

Ilya repeats a sentence he used at the beginning of the chapter.

Илья повторяет фразу, уже встреченную в начале главы.

intratextuality
книге дремной

Ostanin (41) suggests this is a book of fairy tales to be read to children before sleep. Ilya goes back to the moment he introduced this book (when he could not sleep at night), closing (for the moment) the digression.

Останин предполагает, что речь идет о книге сказок, которые читаются детям перед сном (Ostanin 41). Илья возвращается в тому моменту, где он впервые упоминает эту книгу (когда не может заснуть ночью), на время закругляя свое отступление.

explanatory intratextuality
ряба

Reference to “Ryaba the hen”, an Eastern Slavic fairy tale. Read a version of the original here and an English translation here. Animal motif.

Отсылка к “Курочке Рябе”, восточнославянской сказке. Прочитать версию оригинала можно здесь, а английский перевод — здесь.

intertextuality motif folklore
аллаху

The Arabic word for God. Likely related to the fact that “Itil’” is the Turkic name of the Volga. It is also be found in the Tatar language, and most Tatars are Muslims.

Арабское слово, означающее “Бог”. Скорее всего, связано с тем фактом, что “Итиль” — тюркское название Волги. Также встречается в татарском языке, а большинство татар исповедуют ислам.

religion foreign
Итилем

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location language foreign setting
Била-била старуха яйцо — не очень-то. Не преуспел и мужик ее, дряхлый стручок

Rhyme.

Рифма.

rhythm sound rhyme
дряхлый

Ilya describes himself with the same adjective in chapter 1 (R154/E10).

Илья использует то же прилагательное для описания себя в главе 1(R154/E10).

intratextuality
нехитрым надобностям относительно небольшая

Alliteration (n).

Аллитерация (н).

sound stylistic device
стряпчие

Historical term: people who performed various domestic duties at the royal court in the 16th-18th centuries. Later on, in the 18th-19th centuries, judicial officers were called stryapchie. Here the term is related to cooking, suggesting the “challenges” regarding the process of cooking the egg.

Исторический термин: придворные служащие в XVI-XVIII веках. Позже, в XVII-XIX вв. судебных чиновников также стали называть стряпчими. Здесь, употребленно в значении “кухонный”, намекая на “трудности” процесса приготовления яйца.

register/style explanatory
кокнулось

Low-style: to break, crack.

Просторечное: разбиться, треснуть.

register/style
смекаю, смекаю

Colloquial: to catch on, realize.

Разговорное: соображать, понимать.

register/style
опять в недоумении Вы

An apparent allusion to the reader’s experience of reading Ilya’s letter, not just that of Pozhilykh.
